American's like to wait it seems. The same can be said of some hipster cafe-loving Australian's of course,  but long ago I declared that life was too short to wait for my next meal. If I have to wait more than 10 minutes then I'll pick one of the many places around the corner... assuming there are some.

What else can I say except wow? Yum wow. Such a gem in this neighborhood that I'm glad I found. The cooks are super talented obviously from the food, and the staff is spot on attentive and nice. The people who are the managers are working just as hard as the waiters and cooks, which is always a good sign.

Honestly, I came to Universal Cafe expecting to be impressed. But sadly, I was not. I ordered a fried buffalo chicken sandwich. The meat was so dry :( We also ordered a platter with assorted things like salad and scrambled eggs. It looked so oily and unappetizing to me. The only thing I really enjoyed was the beignets here. And even then.. they were only okay. Served with strawberries, some sugar, and white cream, it didn't really wow me like other beignets I've had.
A very traditional breakfast place in this hippie area. A lot of hippie people, but the food was very traditional.
It is weird that I used to hate eating brunch and now I'm a brunch enthusiast?

Now this place is everything I'd like to see in a restaurant.  Their menu is set day-to-day, but I'm assuming a bulk of the menu doesn't change too much in the course of a week or so.  I went with 3 other friends and it was the first meal we had after taking a 6AM flight from Los Angeles.  We waited about 30mins for a table, but it was well worth it.  Our server was very polite as we had many questions about the menu and how things were prepared.
I have a friend who has been providing me the best breakfast recommendations across the country. Today, was no exception.

The Sat waiting line starts after 10:30am. The food is pretty traditional. I had poached eggs with sausage and biscuit. The taste is more selling than the presentation. My friend had scrambled egg with mushroom, and it's too salty.

Clearly this place has a wonderful reputation since it was packed with adoring customers when we arrive. But we didn't need to wait long before we were seated and served. The pouched egg and English muffin was my #1 favorite. But I also highly recommend the French toast with blueberries. Their fruit was particularly fresh and sweet.
I love Universal Cafe.  And I have mad respect for them for opening up in Mission Creek long before it was Mission Creek (actually long after the creek but long before the neighborhood name).

This is out neighborhood joint we love to frequent. Outdoor seating, friendly and prompt service, large plates, and seasonal food. Especially love the brunch menu with it's special smoothie, pastries for sides, French toast and eggs alike, while lunch has some nice options as well. Totally recommend this place when it's nice weather outside!

Pricey. Got our order wrong. Charged us wrong. And the food wasn't even that great. Had to come here because they were the only brunch spot in the area open later than the rest around 2pm. Food was pretty dry. Definitely not worth checking out.
This is one my favorite places in SF! I ate here couple of times and it was perfect every time.

YUM! This was my first time here and so glad I came with my friend. I ran a race on Sunday morning in Alameda, and headed here for brunch afterwards. The wait wasn't very long, though they were pretty crowded (good sign!) and parking was easy (and free!).  Every single item we ordered (bloody mary, donuts, fruit plate, soft scrambled eggs, poached egg, crisp/tart) were all DELICIOUS! It's slightly on the pricier side, but it's in the Mission, so they're catering to a certain type of person, and worth the extra money for how good it is.
I always take my guests from out of town here for brunch. Everything on their menu is fresh and delicious.
$1.25 is added for the health ordinance, Total for 4entrees and 3 OJ came out to be $100
had a really lovely brunch. the scrambled eggs were done perfectly & the porkchop was super tasty.

Solid food (2.5 stars) but not out of this world. The service is subpar as in after 20 min of waiting they never deliver your bill and the place is empty but will happily take your credit card prior to the bill arriving, no friendly chatting with staff, nobody asking how the meal was and today my dining partner and I both received a large stripe of wet paper towel in or salads (so I now question cleanliness too).
The best scramble eggs I've ever tasted and the donuts are to die for...
The best tacos in SFO. Im a huge fan!

I live really close to la taqueria which is great for my taste buds but terrible for my diet (oh well!) I absolutely love this place. Yes, it's nationally ranked, everybody talks about it... its wonderful. All of the above. But something I love about it besides the food is the overall experience. The staff is relatively small, and everybody that works there is so friendly and awesome. Sometimes you even get free roses :) A mariachi band comes in sometimes too which really just adds to the whole experience. Fight for a table, don't get it to-go because sticking around is half the fun. Plus their salsa verde may be the best I've ever had. I'll be back many many more times!

The burritos are small for the price. They have a limited menu ( they couldn't make nachos fort sob) also their burritos did have rice in them. The steak is good but the chicken is boiled and has no flavor

I wasn't a burrito person until La Taqueria. I have eaten three of their burritos in the past week, and I still could eat another one. Their carne asada burritos, which have no rice, are juicy and flavorful. I love their spicy green sauce. I have only tried the carne asada with avocado. It is more on the expensive end for a burrito, but I think it's worth it.
The rumors are true. This place is the best. I've had El Farolito, Taqueria Cancun, and many more up and down the Bay area. This is a QUALITY burrito.

The crispy taco here is pretty yum. I got the carintas tacos and thoroughly enjoyed it. I also got a carne asada quesadilla, which was really good too, but a bit pricey for my taste. While the size of the quesadilla was pretty big, it wasn't worth $7+ to me after adding on avocado. Their strawberry agua fresca was also very refreshing. I'd go back if in the area.
Best burrito in the world... beats el farolito...
Mission...enough said.

Que deliciosa! You know this place is legit when it translates to THE Taqueria. That's akin to saying THE University of California (aka Berkeley). Basically, meaning it's the best of its category. Maybe that was a plug for my alma mater.

It seems like ever since the FiveThirtyEight declared La Taqueria's carnitas burrito the "Best Burrito in America," it's spawned a bunch of hater reviews (there's no rice; there's no al pastor; it's NOT greasy enough...seriously). Hey, not every place is gonna have everything you want guys. And guess what? I don't like rice, I don't like beans, and my favorite burrito from San Diego only has pollo asado, guacamole, and pico de gallo. Simplicity is king!
Get the tacos super and use the green salsa you will not regret it. This is hands down the best tacos I've ever had

My friend wanted to try the mission style buritto.  It's rated the best in a bunch of food things.  when I lived here, I pretty much refused to try mexican food in the bay area.  All I heard was it wasn't as good as SD mexican food.  This was our first stop during my food adventure when I visited.  I was starving so I was ready to eat anything.  I just got off the plane and was ready to hang out and have fun!  I think it was pretty small.  I normally can't finish half but I almost was able to finish the entire thing.. but I was hangry so that could be it..  I ordered the carne asada with sour cream.  I had no idea they put beans in their burittos so I had to pick that out.  I didn't see salsa on the menu and was surprised they didn't put it in the buritto.  Just meat and beans?!  Geez.  It wasn't the greatest buritto but it fulfilled my hunger.
So so good! They are always super busy with really long lines. (Expect a little wait)

The food is shitty. So shitty, it will make you feel shitty. I was very saddened to eat here and be so disappointed. Why do you call yourself THE taqueria if you're so lame?!!!! Life is just not fair.
I was feeling adventurous and had the tongue taco. I recommend it.
Most of the places around here are equally good to me. I've been here quite a few times and love the burritos.  Definitely recommend trying it out.
Look, I know everyone LOVES this place. Here are my issues.
I enjoyed the food a lot here but the aspect I loved the most was the extremely friendly Owner/Cashier who greeted everyone with a smile, joked around and thanked every customer.
Yummi food!
Bestie was visiting and since I had just relocated to SF and hadn't had the chance to try this place since it's always crazy line ups I decided to pop in with my friend.

I got a super veggie, no sour cream and was a little disappointed with no lettuce, no choice of bean type (pinto (not my fav)), kinda on the small side, although that should be a bonus because most are way too big. The price was very reasonable, under $6 before tax. The place was insanely busy at 6PM on a Tuesday but they were obviously working really hard to keep up and the wait was reasonable. I prefer the taquerias where you follow the preparer down the line and they ask you about options.

So this place was names one of the best burrito places so I had to give it a try on my trip to SF. You can take the BART there and it is just a short walk from the station. We arrived just before lunch and grabbed a table and only had to wait about 10 minutes once we placed our order. The place quickly filled up around 12:30 pm on a Saturday so it is best to go before or after the lunch hour.

Love this place with all my heart. I grew up in San Francisco and this was definitely the place my family and I would go to if we wanted burritos. I'm kinda bummed that it has gotten so much publicity lately because I remember the days where the line only took at most 10 minutes. I'm happy La Taqueria is getting the recognition they deserve for their amazing food, but it's sad to see they have raised their prices and made their portions a little smaller. Every time I bring friends here for their first time they are never disappointed, so if you're thinking about trying it, definitely do! I just wish it were still considered a "hole in the wall" so that I could have a hefty burrito for the old prices in 10 minutes or less. Haha. Also their Horchata is the bomb! So good, must try!
Wayyyyyyyyyyyy overpriced. Ridiculously overpriced. food was good but two burritos and two tacos shouldn't be $29 no matter WHERE you go! will not be coming back (unless they lower the prices)

Delish!!!  The chicken burrito was awesome.  All the ingredients are super fresh, especially that avocado.   The best ingredient is their hot green jalapeño sauce on the side...AWESOME!  I didn't get the quesadilla but that will be next time because they looked so good when other customers were ordering them.   Make sure to bring cash only.

Got out of dance class and wanted to try a taqueria we hadn't been to before. The thing that comes to mind is...it's all white people, is this place any good? Haha, well, it is pretty good. The carnitas in my burrito was super flavorful, though I wish they had some special hot sauce of sorts to make it more special.
Best tacos in San Francisco.
carne asada burrito regular, extra meat is the best carne asada burrito i've had in california.     it is a zoo inside at all times so exercise patience.

We ordered 6 tacos (3 carne asada, 1 chicken, 1 lengua, 1 pork) @ $3.75 each. They were great tacos but the lady that was taking our order asked us "if we want everything on it with avocado?" We said yes. Once we were ready to pay the tab it came out to $35 for 6 tacos. They charge $1.65 for avocado per taco. So be careful as they won't disclose that to you upfront. $1.65 is usually how much tacos cost anywhere else, so to charge that amount for avocado is a bit overpriced.

So I found this restaurant from reading an article about this place and this lady said it was Americas best burrito I guess she has been to places all over the US and this was one of her favs. So I decided to give it a try. My sisters and I took BART because as we all know Frisco is bad with parking and some garages charge grip. The BART exit was pretty close. We went on a Saturday afternoon and it was very busy the line was long but it moved quick. the seating area was very crowded so after ordering we found a spot outside to eat. My sister and I shared a burrito the carnitas and a Taco the carnitas. The tacos come with a crunchy tortilla on the inside and a soft on the outside. OMG it was so good. The burrito was pretty small but the flavor was hella good. The green salsa that was outside where we were eating was not that spicy but it had a good flavor to it also.
Some of the best tacos you will ever find.
Awesome tacos, the tongue ones are the best (minus the beans) and they have beer to go with them!
SO of course I wanted to go here because it was given the #1 burrito award but honestly..
Okay so honestly I was a little bummed here. I order a chicken taco & it was filled with beans that pretty much ruined it :(

Came here ready to try the "Best Burrito in the World"...this was definitely far from it. The line was extremely long but I was patient in hoping the outcome would make up for it. Ordered a Dorado Carnitas Super Burrito with everything on it. When I got the burrito it was not dorado and also very small for a "Super" Burrito, it was mostly beans and the condiments, not much meat at all. When I finished the burrito I was not full or close to it, unlike when leaving normal burrito places in the mission I am barely able to finish them. I would rather go to several other places in the mission then have to deal with the lines here and average Mexican food. I recommend going a couple blocks up to Taqueria Cancun or El Foralito for a more satisfying authentic Mexican food experience.

If you are in the mission area, do your hunger a favor and eat something that is to-die-for. Probably the best burrito you will EVER taste. Enough said. Wait is pretty long, but you can stare at their decor in the meantime/ check facebook on your phone. TOTALLY RECOMMEND!!!
Came here b/c it was considered the "Best Burrito" by
Long line and a wait. Doesn't move as fast as El Farolito's
The lines were really long..like really.. on a Sunday afternoon.  There are limited seats, so snatch one fast when u see one!

What the cuss, all the fuss, Durango burrito a must, what a bust...oil smoking when frying burritos, tacos, quesadillas, tortillas...grasshopper, the oil is on fire...cancerous, young one, patience grasshopper...

The perfect combination of casual dining, spectacular ingredients and flavors, with excellent service. Had dinner here recently and absolutely loved it. Can't wait to go back! The duck wings were amazing as was the steak. Simple and delicious.

Bustling, dimly-lit (perhaps a little too dimly) place that felt like you were discovering a new find in the Mission.  Service was nice, competent. But the food, hmmm. How to describe?  While it tasted of quality ingredients and careful preparation, it seemed flavors were out of sync and fighting with each other. It was my first visit, so I had the chicken because the waiter and my companions said Range was known for its chicken. The bird itself was fantastic, but the other flavors on the plate felt like someone was trying to be unique and thoughtful but without tasting it first to see if it really worked. Like a skilled but farsighted painter working without his glasses.  My dining companions, who had referred the place, were equally disappointed and expressed similar frustration with the cod.  Good protein, well-prepared but with other odd, conflicting flavors on the plate. Salads and appetizers were ok. Perhaps it was on off night. Might be worth another try on a future trip to the City.
You must try the braised duck wings in the appetizer menu, there is a slight hint of Chinese fusion at this place, although not pronounced.

Great food, great service but a bit too loud. Real San Francisco experience. I was glad to see chef Rachel here as I knew her from Piccino. I thought that she was ok at Piccino but at Range, she excels.
I had a great meal here tonight!  The celery root soup was delicious, and I loved my salmon with clams.
Given the reviews, I expected more. Went in for the BF's birthday and was really underwhelmed, especially for the prices.
Great dinner spot!

Range hit all the right notes with me and my crew. From the fancy gin cocktail -- which I couldn't have because it turns me into a raging person -- to the amazing food. I had the roasted chicken which is huge and can be shared. My friend had the salmon which was delicious also. Everything was tasty and full of amazing flavors. I can't say enough about this place. The ambiance is pretty incredible too.
solid place, good drinks (paper plane was great)

Everything was amazing.  For starters we got the duck wings and the pasta and they were both awesome.  The duck literally fell off the bone.  For entree I ordered the duck as well, it was so amazing.  My friends raved about their dishes too, but I was too focused on my entree too try theirs ;). Cocktails were great too.  All around amazing dinner.

After hearing friends rave about Range for years, I was really excited to check out this restaurant. I must admit that when I'm in the neighborhood, I usually hit Beretta as I feel like their menu is stellar.
My girlfriend and I love this place. The decor is just OK and the service is generally pretty good, but the food and drinks are just amazing!

Wow, the menu looked so great!  But, dang.  We had an important dinner with out of town guests, had made an 8:30 reservation, and waited, and waited. The earlier diners had arrived late for their reservation, which apparently allowed them to spill into ours.  We waited for over 45 minutes on a busy Friday night, despite a reservation made a week earlier, with no place to stand but along a thin hall across from the beverage station.  When I saw their desserts just arriving at their table at after 9:00, my stomach sank.  REALLY?  I don't know what restaurants' policies are with late-comers for their own reservations, but this blows.   We weren't able to order until an HOUR after our original reservation.  And, no, I don't really like to eat dinner at 10pm. Drinks took a long time to arrive.The food was...OK.  My trout was fabulous, but the cod?...meh.  The staff did gift us with a couple of appetizers for our patience (!)--Personally for this, I would have expected a bottle of wine.  I will never go to this place again. For the price, it should be impeccable.
We've been going to Range on a fairly regular basis for the past two years. The food is generally very solid, but the service can be variable.
Really like this place. Food is strong, always good service and not hard to get a table. Menu is a little limited but that is not an issue for me.

Range has been my favorite restaurant for several years and I look forward to frequenting it often as I live in the neighborhood.  The food and service was great as usual tonight.  However, I was surprised that precisely two hours after we sat down for a family dinner, we were asked to pack up and leave by the lead hostess, coincidentally right as we were on our way out anyhow. But rather than allow us to be on our way, she continued to supervise our departure and inform us that we dined 30 minutes too long. Never have I encountered this at Range, nor any respectable restaurant for that matter, but it left quite a sour taste in my mouth, and I don't anticipate rushing back there anytime soon.

Meh. Super disappointed. Went here for my birthday and I was so looking forward to finally trying this place. Even with a reservation, we waited over 20 minutes to be seated and then another 15 to be served with drinks. By the time we ordered and got our food, it had already been an hour!! The best thing here is their cocktail selection. Ordered the chicken like mousse, special appetizer pasta, chicken entree, fish entree, and the pork shoulder. Everything was too salty but without any flavor. The fish was bland, chicken overcooked. The pork shoulder was good, but nothing special, especially at their price point. We got the Napoleon for dessert and it was awful. Wasn't even a Napoleon and the filling tasted like cheap out of the can strawberry frosting. My espresso was salty. Yea, salty. Truly disappointing.

Trendy spot with a fun crowd. The menu is up-to-date for any foodie and they even serve smooth-temperatured Kölsch on tap. (A+ for that.) Maybe not the best spot to bring your creature-of-habit parents as it can be loud and familiar ingredients are fused with exotic and unique edibles. I was quite impressed to find 'California' king salmon as an entrée. Mom said it "didin't exist" but later sessions on Wikipedia proved the contrary. Overall a pleasant evening where French influence blends nicely with the California palate. Perhaps I will return with a group, maybe for a birthday party, so we could better compete with the other merrymaking and festive patrons.

Holy moly pork shoulder! Don't be deterred by the coffee rub. Get it. And then get it for dessert. Seriously, it's delicious, melt-in-your mouth meat, and although my husband enjoyed his steak (done perfectly medium-rare), he had order envy. We also had the chicken liver mousse which I thought was fantastic, though others in our party were less impressed. The desserts weren't as stellar as I'd hoped they would be. Not bad, but I think I would have been happier ordering a port or after-dinner-drink. Service is friendly and attentive but not overbearing. For a special night out in the city, this was a great spot for us. Yum.

Every dish was delicious. Great pacing, we were there for 1.5 hours but never felt like we were waiting for anything. The drinks are good, but a little expensive. I think we lucked out and got a good table. Our corner table was far away from everyone else. Some of the side 2-person tables looked like they may be a little too close together for comfort. For a SF restaurant with great reviews, it was surprisingly intimate and not packed. This is a huge plus. The service felt very personal. They aren't taking on more work/tables than they can handle.
I thought it was okay but certainly not up to all the hype it gets. Our service was also exceptionally slow.
3.5. - it was interesting. I'm sure many people love this place, I thought it was alright. Probably wouldn't come here again, but good to try.

Range is known to house the most beatiful women trying to break it in the world of top model, but that's not why this place urks me. It's a little too pretentious. The woman who stand at the front, waiting to seet you, look dreadfully bored. Like they - in New York. At night this place gets packed with the young, hip and trendy city dshould be sipping mojito's on a photo shoot in Miami, not acting like a hostess at a Range  wellers. During the day it's a mix of tourists and business people. I've gone there to eat for lunch only. It was decent food, like an upscale diner. Nothin' special, expect for the 6 foot, Niaomi Campbell look a like who politley served us our lunch.
Very meh... I have walked by this place for years and wanted to go. Finally got to choose a restaurant for my birthday dinner and.... was very unimpressed.
REVIEW #310--because Range reminds me of the chic 310 area (except Compton which I guess can represent the surrounding sketchiness that is the Mission)

When I heard my friend had made us a reservation at Range, the contrarian in me came out. "Ugh, another place where I'll spend $60 getting one drink and a piece of chicken in a pretentiously-unpretentious Mission restuarant." Yeah, I'm getting a little jaded.
Trying to be clever, rather than telling my friend that I was near, I checked in on yelp and said, "I'm in range." Having just returned from Europe, I was craving for something very San Franciscan.

Awesome awesome place! Fun ambiance, great service, and fresh food. It's one of my favorite dining spots in the Mission. The food is simple but inventive (e.g., coffee bean + pork chops) and the drinks are really good too. It's a very fun place to come with a small group of friends. The dessert was also superb

The food was ok but it appeared to be overpriced for what it is. There are many new restaurants in the Mission that serve better food at a lower price. It did not help that it took over an hour for our food to arrive.
Great dinner spot in the mission. The menu is fresh and interesting. The food didn't disappoint.
Loved Range! It's the classic farm to table restaurant with a Mission twist. When I bit into my seared albacore appetizer, the ingredients were so fresh, and the flavors were intense.
Awesome farm to table (and not in the cliché way) style food.  I love the ambiance (art-deco). Great drinks,  great wine list,  amazing food, ORDER DESSERT :-)
Pro tip: if your making reservations on a busy day (Fri or Sat) get them earlier in the day so you don't get impacts of an entire day of running over capacity dumped on you.
Agree with many of the yelpers here that Range is a very solid choice.  Love, Love this place: food, ambiance, service, wine, and dessert from start to finish, you just don't want it to end.
So. I was kind of disappointed with the service at this place.

The BF choose Range in SF for date night #2: chicken liver mousse with frisée salad was so yummy we ordered another one to go! smoked trout rillette with pickled beets, horseradish cream (but tasted tangy and not like horseradish at all) with trout roe and rye toast (we liked everything in this dish but could have been good without the smoked trout rillette - it was almost like canned tuna consistency) we especially liked the trout roe! strip loin roast with hasselback potatoes, lacinato kale, pecorino and rye breadcrumbs was just eh and not worth $29 cause the cut of meat wasn't good and it was just too chewy for me even at medium rare, roasted chicken with with caramelized squash, toasted farro, almonds and basil gremolata was a pretty big dish and tasted ok for $25, dessert was the goat cheesecake with spiced pecan spelt shortbread, and some sort of berry sorbet and was super yummy! Drinks were the garden party (I really liked it) and the BF got the barbarella. Our waiter kristian was really good too! We noticed they forgot to charge us fr the drinks that were to be transferred from the bar and only charged us for the wine we ordered with dinner so we told our waiter. he wanted to check on it but the BF gave his card to pay for the drinks at the bar regardless. Kristian came back and said they settled it in front and they werent going to charge us and thanked us for our honesty. Great service with great food. We will def come back again and try different entrees.

WAY to small portions. Really tasty but entrees the size of an appetizer.  They charged 28 for the 6 oz steak and "potato"( one small potato) would rather pay $38 and not leave hungry. Would go back if bigger portions. Cheap looking tables too :)
YUM

From start to finish- a true culinary and wine delight! To start to duck wings are so good, we discussed coming back just to order this crispy delicious crunchy treat. Greens and veggies are very fresh and seasonal. The wine list is respectable. Ambiance and menu feels very PAC heights tasty dinning meets mission culture awareness. Definitely coming back :)

I understand that Range is among the finer restaurants in San Francisco, but for what it's worth, I prefer its competitors -- other farm-to-table wonders with creative chefs that are numerous in SF.  Here are my reasons for giving it 3 stars, rather than 4 or 5.  Know that I base my comparison on Nopa, which readily receives all 5 of my stars, and where my dining experiences have always been 100% perfect.

Came here from out of town for dinner with friends. We managed to get a reservation for 4 on a Monday night on short notice, and the place was pretty packed when we got there. The bread from tartine bakery next door is delicious - make sure you request some (free of charge). Unfortunately their kitchen was taking longer than expected and we waited about an hour for our food to arrive. We were getting antsy, but they won us over with their great customer service. They gave us a complimentary dish of olives while we were waiting and a plate of almond nougat bites at the end. The servers were very nice and accommodating. One of my friends barely ate her dish and they asked if she didn't like it at the end. They ended up comping her entire dish and also comped one of the sides that came late.

This place is pretty good for your staple Italian dishes but honestly the pizzeria is better. When my boyfriend and I were seated, we literally were sat next to a couple (looked like an awk first date) who was in the process of walking out because the girl wanted to go to the pizzeria instead.
I've been wanting to go here for about 8 years now and for some reason it just never lined up.  So last night I was pretty excited to finally make the trip.

We went here last night for our anniversary dinner. We thought it would be quiet because it was a Monday night around 8:30, but the place was lively. Still, service and food were wonderful and fast. I tried the featured pomegranate bellini, which was extremely refreshing and not too sweet. We started with the prosciutto-mascarpone ravioli and the mint pasta with mushrooms and nettles. My husband who is from Italy wasn't too impressed with the ravioli, but I loved it; he preferred the mint dish. Overall, both were delicious though! We ordered the roasted chicken with mushrooms and swapped out the mashed potatoes for the cheesy polenta, which was truly amazing! We were pretty full after all this, but we still ordered the flourless chocolate cake to split. It's sort of dry, but the rice gelato that accompanies it is interesting. Our server was kind and informed, and she never lingered too long - it was our anniversary, after all. We will definitely be back to make our way through the entire menu!
Great!

This is a sad thing to say because Delfina on 18th St has been one of our standby restaurants. But the food last week was mediocre, and not just one dish but across the board for a party of four. Worse, I heard the same thing from a Delfina-admiring friend. Has there been a change in the kitchen? I have no idea, but I'm in no hurry to go back.

A food obsessed friend of mine from New York absolutely raved about this place and said it was a must for anyone in SF. I'm visiting from Australia and was not disappointed. For starters we shared the grilled calamari, crispy Parmesan cheese, and prosciutto with pear. I am not usually a calamari fan but these little guys were so soft and tender, and came on a bed of tiny rice beans and salad. Wrap a piece of prosciutto in pear and die and go to heaven. We then had the anchovy pasta, lamb tartelli and roast duck - all were incredible and cooked to perfection. The duck was my favourite but if you're an anchovy fan you won't be disappointed by the salty goodness of that pasta! No room for dessert!
I was surprised by their salad. Will go try other soon.
Excellent service. The pasta melts into your mouth. Great ambiance. Noisy. Not very good for large groups
15 years ago we ate here nice!  Now a few days ago dinner again and was very good tasty food and service was fine. Had to ask for bread & butter.  My entree $19 pasta was more like a appetizer.

Probably the best place I have ever dined. I am a server and was just amazed on how much knowledge the servers had. They seriously could answer any question about any wine that they have on the menu!!!
Get the panna cotta.

So what's the hype all about? My sister said, "You've got to try the spaghetti. It's just like the ones we ate in Italy." I secretly called her bluff on this, but dang it she was right. Perfectly cooked spaghetti with that simple tomato sauce, which tastes anything but simple.  It's $9 for a half portion and $13 for a full.  Don't be a fool. Order the full size.  Take it home for leftover if it lasts that long.

OMG!!!! The pasta in this restaurant was so amazingly delicious that my husband and I went for seconds and then came back one more time during our trip to San Fran. After eating such good pasta here, it's difficult to go to other places where usually the pasta is sub par even if they advertise their pasta as being 'home made' and 'al dente'. After eating at Delfina it has been certainly difficult to eat pasta anywhere else!

The wait is always long here, so be prepared. I've been coming to Delfina regularly for the past couple of years and I always leave happy. The ambiance is great here, whether you're on a date, with a close friend, or celebrating a birthday dinner. Not once have I had bad service which is not something that you can say often about a place.
This place is really good and loved the atmosphere.  We really enjoyed the cauliflower pasta and spaghetti and meatballs!! We literally wanted to lick the plate!!
Always without fail, very delicious. Duck Sugo pappardelle deserves a mention!

We were walking by and happened to stumble upon this little gem! The air was filled with oven-baked goodness, so we followed our noses in. The greeter was very nice and had us seated right away during peak dinner hours (surprising for SF dining). The place is quite big but the tables are all very close to each other...At one point, I watched an older man try to scoot from the booth out between two tables and there was only about 8" of space between each table. It was a bit uncomfortable, but luckily we were seated on a nice corner table a bit less crowded. I also felt like the decor/atmosphere was a bit lacking. Nothing very unique or memorable about it. And it didn't really seem to match the type of food offerings.. Which felt mismatched. The food was really good -- we ordered their version of a spaghetti carbonara, which was rich and hearty. We also got the veal saltimbocca which was also very well prepared. However, I'm not sure that out of all the "good food" we had, anything really stood out as *exceptional* -- I definitely had a great time and enjoyed the food, but I'm not sure if anything was particularly memorable. Hence, the 4 stars instead of 5.

Excited as we were about our experience here it was not really memorable except for small portions that kept you wanting more. Olives I love and We fell for them here along with the fried dough ravis with thin sliced salami.
Fortunate to nab their last (Saturday eve) 5:30p reservation online, as we arrived just minutes before their open.
Amazing food and service! We started with the warmed olives and the gnocchi fritto and proscuitto. Like perfect puffs of lightness!

Delicious meal! The escarole and fig salad was simple, yet exquisite. The pappa al pomodoro is a nice tomato bread soup. Overall, vegetarian options are very limited for entrees.  The panna cotta is the only way to go for dessert.

This place is great. There's always a wait so one day I got off work early, and decided to pop in to see if they had a table available. And they did! First they seated us in the kind of awkward area between the restaurant and bar, but then we moved to a table in the bar area, so it was fine. All the tables in the dinner area were already reserved.
This is a very 'in' place.  Excellent food and wine selection.  The service is excellent. Book early because it's hard to get in!  But it's a must on the list of restaurant to go to in San Francisco!
Delfina made our Sunday night.

The food, service, ambiance was incredible...but the reason I will go back is for the hot waiter with the beard, tattoos and badonkadonk....seriously, i wasnt in his section and still felt like samantha in the episode of sex and the city where she sits alllllll night in smiths section and keeps ordering things to be the last one there to take him home...sigh

There's a great vibe at Defina and the food was exceptionally tasty. It's partnered with a good wine list, with something for everyone. Service was a little inattentive at times, but always friendly. Will return.
Scrumptious menu through and through. Professional, happy staff.
Simply a perfect meal. Everything done right.

Love this restaurant! They have two restaurants next to each other, one is the pizzeria and the other is an Italian restaurant. I have dined at both and am happy to report that both are amazing. Since they are great, so be prepared to wait. In the regular restaurant, the white bean and squid salad and quail were delicious. I am happy with every pizza I tried at the Pizzeria.
Shocked I've never written a review. Let's change that.
I'm in love.
this place is great.  enough space between tables.  not too loud.  great food.  great affordable wine selection.  what else do you want?

Probably the best pasta in San Francisco...yes, including Flour & Water.  The food is excecellent...service delightful...atmosphere best described as full of energy ( yes, on the loud side, but conversation not difficult) . Whenever we're in San Francisco we always have a meal at Delfina, and fortunately we're here fairly often.

Good Italian food in a fun setting.  My friends began with the sea bass conserva appetizer (poached sea bass pureed and spread on crostini) and the olive oil tasting (one type of olive oil from Sardinia and the other from Sicily).  Both were great.

So I avoided this place for the longest time because I heard mixed reviews from my friends and the menu never seemed interesting to me maybe because I didn't understand the words they used on there.  I finally came over here 2 nights ago for a quick bite.  When I said I didn't understand the words they use on their menu I meant it.  You should have seen me asking about EVERYTHING.  I was starting to feel a little embarrassed asking so many questions but they were very informative and helpful with a smile the entire time.  Our first server was so knowledgeable! I felt like I needed her like fish needs water.

Hearty, vibrant, relaxed restaurant. Had the best calamari, spaghetti, and chicken with mashed potatoes here. There are probably more things that are worth trying, but you can never go wrong with those. Also we really loved the pana cotta! 5 stars would come again!

In the past, we have always looked forward to eating at Delfina but our last visit a week or so ago was a disappointment. Service was poor. The server forgot one of our entrees and it ended up coming 15-20 minutes after the other entree and all of our dishes which arrived at the same time for some strange reason.
Not vegetarian friendly.

I was recently reminded of a mediocre dinner I had here about a year ago when I vowed to write a review.  I was so disappointed.  The ridiculous crowd, the long wait even with reservations and the food which was about the 50th percentile of Italian food in SF.
Incredible lentil soup & the best pita ever!  Nothing fancy, and not in a busy restaurant area, this Mediterranean food is well worth seeking out.

We went there on weekdays. Its cozy place with great paintings on full wall complementing the ambiance. Chicken Plate was good but their Falafel were outstanding. Best falafel ever tasted. Quick tip: don't order too much coz they have complimentary pita and sauces.
So good! One of the few places in the bay that doesn't have watery hummus. While it's not true Lebanese like the app will tag it, It's better than most places.
really tasty friendly family owned place.  the meat with feta was superb.  Lentil soup was great.

The food is very good -- i liked the Shish Taouk (chicken) wrap which was made with obviously fresh pita which was toasted crisp and made the entire wrap even better.  Great flavors, although perhaps a tad too much lettuce.  The baklava, however, I've had better.   Although the young woman and man were exceedingly nice & friendly, they need just a tad more learning on intuitive service -- as in knowing when to check in at table to see if anything else is needed, clear plates and ask about dessert, etc -- it's really small place, so not that difficult.  But I did like it overall.
Clean, music, good service, interesting menu. The food was good, I thought similar to mediterranean.
I had the Fetta with lamb. 100% delicious. Warm pita, delicious tahini herb something or other to dip it in, and tomato-onion spicy chutney-ish thing are complimentary. I'll be back. Maybe tomorrow.

I hate to provide a low review for this family run business, but it is not without consideration. Tried the shawerma wrap-- bland and tough pieces of meat every other bite. The breading had an excessive amount of flour dustings which created a dry mouth feel and left everything that it touched coated in flour. Attempted this restaurant again the other day and ordered baba ghanoush and stuffed falafel. Baba ghanoush was flavorless and required an extra squeeze of a whole lemon (which we asked for and did) and another good pinch of salt. While the doctoring up provided much needed brightness to the dish, the eggplant did not have any flavor. Stuffed falafel was good when dipped in the yogurt dipping sauce. Nicely fried and moist in the center. As for the complimentary pickled veg and olives, there's a slight off taste to the pickled veg and the olives are okay but extremely salty (needs a quick rinse from the brine). Service: The male wait staff was good. The female wait staff can benefit in some hospitality training. Perhaps it's what we ordered, but overall, most of the food did not taste fresh and lacked seasoning. I tried giving this place a second chance but the dining experiences were not memorable to return for a third.

I am here again, just to recommend you this restaurant, I have never tried this kind of food before, but this is my fourth time in less than 3 months, because I really like it, I can say it is something different. You will find variety in plates then you can pick up depending of your preferences, but you can ask what you should eat and the guys are willing to help you out right away; I can say it is fast services, you do not have to wait for long time to be serviced and the billing time is good as well. Let me tell you this restaurant sometimes is full of people, which mean they have a really good food. Sorry I am a food lover.

As a Middle Eastern foodie I'm disheartened that this eatery passes as a quality Arabian/Middle Eastern restaurant with a 4 star rating.  The staff is this super nice Palestinian family and they were very welcoming (and excited I spoke Arabic) but I'm sorry, that doesn't make up for the food.

The seating area is good compared to other places close by. The food was also good. We got a mixed platter and a chicken plate. Both were good. The gave complimentary olives, bread and olive oil which was really nice.
No alcohol, but great tea.

How did I not know about this place? It's about as good as Oren's Hummus Shop in Palo Alto. Great hummus. I think Oren's has better chicken though. The atmosphere leaves some to be desired, though it's not too bad.
Really like Old Jerusalem. Small place, great food, extremely affordable.

Excellent food.  The hummus is so delicious.  And the baba ganoush has a great authentic smokey flavor.  Exactly the same taste that you would eat in Palestine.  I loved the salad and the flavors of the kifta kebab (They were a little dry.  Not sure if it's because they were sitting a while before I ate.  Still delicious.) chicken and rice.  Bread was so good.  It had a nice chew to it.
I love Hummus here which comes with a spicy sauces. This place is worth to give a try.
Good quantity and Tasty food

LOVE this place. Their chicken shawerma is fantastic, they serve it with a nice plate of olives and pickled radishes...my only complaint is that sometimes I want to go by on Mondays, and am disappointed when they aren't open!
GOOD: Unique taste, Food selection.
The food was good, but it surprised me they charged us $14.95 for veg combo. The menu listed as $13.95. Need to fix their menu.

Love this place! The food is delicious and the atmosphere is fabulous. It feels really authentic. It's so cheap too. We shared the vegetarian combo which tasted amazing and a chicken & rice dish. The chicken was cooked to perfection. I think it's just taken my top spot in San Francisco position! Great service too.
This is our go-to spot. It's always got a steady stream of customers, but we never have to wait for a table.
When it comes to traditional middestreen food HERE IS THE SPOTS. ...great food cozy spot the arabic coffee and konafah were delicious

Shawarma, rice, and hummus? Yes please! This place is located a block south of 24th and Mission in the somewhat o_O part of the Mission District. The walls are painted of the Old City of Jerusalem, and have a bunch of tables for either 2 or 4 people.
I honestly don't understand all the five star reviews.
Please note: 3 stars because it is pricey!

Simply said, Old Jersualem's is fantastic!! I'm not an easy critic when it comes to Middle Eastern food, originally from NY and having spent time in Egypt; I've yet to have a meal that wasn't wonderful. The Chick shawarma consistently has the most soft and supple marinated chicken. I've had in SF. Their hummus is perfect; smooth and creamy. When getting take-out they typically turn a meal around in 15 minutes and stand by their timing estimates, they're very respectful on their customer's time. Highly recommend!
(+): great food, good appetizers. that onion and tomato sauce is KILLER, how do they make that?!

I almost cried when I ate there earlier today.  Beautiful and friendly staff serving beautiful, delicious food.  Come hungry, lots of food for what you pay for.  I'm super stoked to try one of their lavash wraps.  All that goodness in a flavorful pouch.

This is a great restaurant if you're having the urge to get some Arabic food.  Me and 2 friends of mine dropped by here yesterday and one of my friends suggested this restaurant to me way back and at this day we were in the neighborhood so we decided to drop by. Their menu is simple: About  50 Items are on the Menu and that's about it but most are good. I had the Shawarma sandwich which is about 14 inches long and filled with freshly cooked and combined with beef and it was so good! I only ate 1/4 of the sandwich because it's too big and tasty and it quickly filled me because I'm really not a big anymore and I save the rest for that night's dinner (Yeah it was that big of a sandwich!) My other 2 friends got the combination plates + we also had a plate of Baba Ghanoush with freshly baked pita bread that just got out of the oven...OH SO GOOD!!! :) We had a great time dining here and I will be back here and I will let you on what else I might find. A Highly recommended place if you happen to be in the Mission district in San Francisco.....
Consistency,  that what I'm talking about , service, food, ambiance, today I had chicken shawarma flavored and juicy , Kunafa desert yummy I love it !!!

The best Middle Eastern food I had in the Bay Area. And I've been to quite a few places. Their hummus is fantastic-- try the fatta with meat, which is a combination of warm hummus with meat inside, which is absolutely delicious. Another thing that is really important to me is that the place will have good pita breads, and not only are their pita bread is great, but they will also give you free "refills" on it, unlike many other places.

My first time here tonight. After many previous reviewers suggested it we got a combination plate, stuffed falafel and chicken shawarma. Everything was tasty and the meats were juicy, The falafel in particular was excellent. Fried really crisp on the outside and moist on the inside, very flavorful. I got a tea with my meal and it was really good with the fresh mint. We tried a kunafa for dessert. They have a tray already prepared from which they heat a slice for you. This causes the shredded phyllo to be soggy. The overall taste was good, but it wasn't very warm, so no stringy cheese and the soggy phyllo made the texture a little unappealing. I also got an Arabian coffee with dessert and it was great; very strong and well spiced. The price for two of us was under $50 which I think is great considering all of the overpriced and poor quality middle eastern food in the city. Overall we really liked the food and I am sure we will come again. Everyone eating near us really seemed to enjoy their food as well.
Best falafel balls!
Decent quality food along with good service.

We came here because of favorable reviews on Check Please Bay Area and Yelp. We left wondering, what's the big deal? The food is barely average. The prices are high for the food that you get. Everything is about a third over priced. And they nickel and dime you. They charged $1.50 for an extra sauce that was originally free, but don't tell you until the end. We won't be back.
Full House on a Friday night! Luckily, my friend had reservations for 12, which pretty much took up about 1/3 of the restaurant. You're welcome :P
I make great hummus.
Went on Wednesday night- 20 min wait. They take reservations however.

Food is kinda nasty. Tried their chicken shawarma and the half chicken plate..I  bet they cooked the chicken  month ago and they just microwave it before serving it. Don't recommend this to any one out there. There are a plenty of good Middle eastern restaurants in SF

We had a very nice dinner here on a Tuesday night,  a little reunion with my husband and two grown children, one in town for business.  The dinner was mostly talk accompanied by good wine and good food.  The staff handled our dribbling in very well and our waitress gave us just the right amount of attention along with a good wine reccommendation.

My husband refused to believe that we had the right place as we drove by the seemingly unmarked restaurant at night. There is a sign on the window, but no way to see it at night except when you are standing in front of it.
Their cheeseburger is simply HEAVEN.
Heirloom Cafe is our favorite restaurant in San Francisco.
Came here on a weeknight as party of 2. It is a quaint, slightly hidden restaurant as there is no visible sign when trying to find it at night. Dark and intimate, beautiful interior.
Nice and charming place
'Simple and well-executed' sums up my experience here.
Came here twice -once in a large group and once for 3 people.

We had a lovely dinner at Heirloom Cafe with a party of 4 for our monthly "One of Everything" dinner club. The decor is your typical shabby chic/hip/rustic farmhouse feel and paired well with the food offerings.

Heirloom Cafe was wonderful! I took my boyfriend here for his 30th birthday dinner and it was perfect. The decor is chic and reflects their farm to table ideals - raw wooden tables, pretty sconces on the wall, and delicate, lacy window dressings. You can look over and see them working in the kitchen which give it a nice home-y feel.

Sometimes you just want a nice, no-risk dinner because you have those moments in your life when comfort becomes a priority over culinary audacity. That's exactly the mood you should have when you get ready for dinner at the Heirloom Cafe set in a refurbished Victorian. Everything was presented immaculately but there was not a bit of daring to be found in any of the plates. I wouldn't have minded maybe one surprise, but none were to be experienced that evening. The service also felt a bit off. It was polite but a bit off-putting. When I sardonically asked where the heirloom tomatoes were on the menu, the server curtly told me they were not in season yet.

This is my new found favorite restaurant. It is in the quiet part of the Mission at the corner of Folsom and 21st and there is no sign outside. When you walk in the restaurant, you are immediate immersed in the cozy warmth of a dimly lit living room. I love sitting at the communal table to chat with my fellow diners. You know it is a good restaurant when people eating there are all foodies, which is the case here. The restaurant us known for the pole bean salad with meshed dates. OMG that was a very unexpected combination and so delicious and refreshing. I also ordered a duck dish which was also great. Overall, an awesome place and I can't wait to try other dishes!

Everything was perfect.  The space itself is rustic yet elegant.  You definitely wouldn't expect much just seeing it from the street, but what a hidden treasure.  The staff is friendly and knowledgeable.  We arrived 20 minutes early and they seated us without a problem.  We opted not to do the tasting menu, although it looked delicious.  Had the corn soup, scallops, duck breast, and papardelle.  I was a little underwhelmed by the papardelle because I've had that dish done better at a couple of other restaurants.  But everything else was delicious.  Perfect combinations of tastes and textures.

Heirloom Cafe was at the 2014 SF Street Food Festival and the fresh mint lemonade ($3) quenched my thirst. After seeing so many people walking around with this drink, I had to try one. It was 16 oz of refreshing lemonade that cooled me down and had just the right amount of mint. If I hadn't been so full, I would have also ordered the pulled pork sandwich.
Shh! Don't tell anyone. Heirloom should remain a secret.

Fantastic food. Scallops and duck were excellent, the bacon and onion tart was mediocre imo. Service was great also. They let you taste their wine by the glass, before committing to one, which was a really nice touch. Good decor with open kitchen. One the whole, a completely enjoyable experience.

Charming decor. Warm greetings by the host and owner. Attentive service. Delicious food. I had an incredible corn soup, a scallop/mushroom entree and crisp wines. The menu is delightful in its range of offerings without trying to please the whole world. Trying to figure out how I've lived in the Bay Area five years and just now made this incredible discovery. (Introduced by a friend who attends ODC performances a few blocks away.) A versatile setting that left me feeling like I captured a moment in Paris ...
Be warned, don't come here on an empty stomach!

Just had the *best* burger here!!!!! It came in an English Muffin with a very very tasty patty that was clearly home made and fresh. SO delicious and very original burger. The wine pairings are amazing and very reasonably priced. My partner got the steak and it was also delicious with another amazing wine pairing. Had the sweet corn dessert which was also original and yet delectable. The service was very attentive, we got seated immediately, and found the atmosphere to be casual and unpretentious. Would definitely come back!

This is a hidden gem in San Francisco. Matt and his team are a what you seat is what you get culture. We've been going for two years and the staff pretty much hasn't changed which is a rare sight in the industry. The food is honest. The decor is simple. The wine list is understated in how good it is. We love that this place doesn't have the pretentiousness that is going on in so many other places in the city. And with a little forewarning, you can usually get a table. I just hope it doesn't get more popular (it is always full). Recommend anything off the menu. Let them guide you on wine. There is an off-menu burger which is pretty special. They also do winemaker dinners and brunch if you ask or get on their mailing list. Have been to a few and they are always incredible experiences. Great place for a date, for friends, and for family. Note that some of the tables are shared tables - not for everyone.
The food was incredibly good, one of the best meals I've had in SF.
This is a really lovely restuarant
Cracking wine list and nice staff. Needs good food to match the wine though

My wife and my favorite restaurant in the city right now. Was just there for Fathers Day yesterday. And had a fantastic brunch. Eggs Benedict cooked to perfection. A fantastic pea soup to open and light yogurt and berries to close. Also the croissant French toast was ridiculous.

So happy to have rediscovered Heirloom. This place is wonderful. I hadn't been here in years due to disappointment after 2 prior meals. A couple friends recently mentioned how much they like this place so I decided to give it another chance. It was superb. Service was effective and thoughtful and the food we ordered was SO yummy. 10/10 for both the fennel and feta salad (there were also walnuts and other goodies in it) and the lamb pappardelle. I almost went back the night after this meal, it was that good.

Four of us for a friend's birthday.  Other than the hefty prices of wine, everything was perfect from the minute we were greeted to the minute we departed.  We sampled almost everything on the menu - a choice of cheeses; burrata, roasted asparagus, shallot vinaigrette, toasted levain; salad of fennel, fava beans, Mt. Vikos feta, walnuts; sea scallops, cauliflower puree, maitake mushrooms, ramps; spigarello, garlic, currants, breadcrumbs; roasted paprika-agave carrots, St. Benoit yogurt, seared bavette steak, gigante beans, baby artichokes, breadcrumbs, lemon aioli... and something delicious for dessert, which I forget what it was.  Absolutely EVERYTHING was delicious.  We even found a reasonably priced Argentinian Malbec.   All told, the bill came to $300 and change, plus tip.  The service, decor, atmosphere were classic.  Will definitely be going back!
Cheese burger is off the hook!
The Food:
burger.

We are here last night and had a great meal. We shared the burrata with roasted asparagus, which was heavenly. We both had the lamb ragu pappardelle for our main courses, which was also delicious. The service was attentive and friendly. I will definitely be back!

Everything we had here was wonderful. We brought a couple of vegetarians along with us as well, and the staff were very accommodating. Nice ambiance. Attentive waiter. We had their entire selection of cheeses as well as most of their entrees. The sides were especially delightful with a special shoutout to their carrots as well as the olive oil cake from their dessert menu. Would highly recommend this place. I love when a place outshines my expectations.
I've eaten at Heirloom Case several times, and the food has always been fantastic. If you want to go out for a really nice American meal in the Mission, Heirloom is a great value.

Fell into dinner here by accident and it was one of the best meals I've had in a long time. I feel bad even posting a review because I want to keep this place a secret to myself. Couldn't give a bigger recommendation. A+.

I haven't felt compelled to write a review in a long time, but my experience at this place was so bad that I really have no choice.  For $40/person for brunch, I expect a place to 1) not try to seat me at the worst table in the entire place when it's half-empty post brunch-rush; 2) not be too cool for ketchup, jam and whole wheat bread; 3) not completely forget about part of my order; 4) not accidentally overcharge me.  On top of all that, the food was boring (eggs and a piece of toast; uninspired french toast.)  How this place gets 4+ stars is beyond me.

4th time here and still one of my favorites. Salads are interesting and incredibly fresh. Great wine list. Had business friends from out of town at the community table that we had to ourselves.  Very enjoyable. They appreciated finding a neighborhood spot rather than hitting the financial district regular spots.
Dear Heirloom Cafe,
Cozy place

This restaurant is hard to spot, as it looks like someone's house or apartment from the outside. Once you find the door, you'll see that it's a full restaurant with a short menu. The prices are on the more expensive side and portions are modest (remind me of portions in Europe), but the flavor and taste is very good and high quality. We ordered sweet potato bread to start with and I got the sea scallops (note: this dish came with 4-5 scallops) with cauliflower puree. It was a small portion but very tasty.

Matt the owner shows off an amazing but reasonably priced wine list. I've recently gone twice. Once for a special wine pairing event and then brought work colleagues from out of town for a neighborhood restaurant experience. Both times the food, drink, service and ambience were exceptional. It's a low key location with high quality, approachable food with non-Mission, non-Downtown prices. The highlights were the Corison Cabernet, burrata/asparagus dish, gnocchi, shaved fennel salad, bavette steak,  and Cod with seared skin. Yum.

Wow. Service and atmosphere are great, but the food! Do not under any circumstances miss the gnocchi. Chicken, scallops, and an amazing burrata/asparagus appetizer, which may have shortened my life by 6 months but who cares. Let them pick wines--they're astute and not out to run up the tab
Why do people out put up with such poor services with ok food?  Cheap prices? Tradition? The new proprietors have took on the bad attitude of the previous owner.

Braved the curry facial in this little hole in the wall spot with a friend to grab some food. Horrendous service. Felt like they threw the food at us and watched angrily as we quickly shoveled our food into our face so we could be out of their way.

So if you eat at Yamo you know that the service is lacking. You go for the delicious cheap food. I have been eating here for years now dispite the terrible service but my experience last night was probably the worst I've had there. I order what I usually get, the cold noodle salad with chicken and a tea leaf salad as an appitizer . I saw my order come up and sit on the bar while the lady who takes orders and is generally the most unpleasant, took a walk-in togo order. By the time my food was delivered the chicken was cold. Two bites in and I had to spit out a piece of chicken because it was so rubbery I thought it was raw. I brought this to her attention, only to be told that it was the knuckle part of the chicken and that I should eat it. Not only that I got my appitizer halfway through my main course and water halfway through my meal....It's safe to say that I am more than willing to put up with bad service for good food, But if I am getting sub-par food and terrible service I think it's time to find somewhere else for a cheap fix. Sorry Yamo I won't be back after being treated like SH#$%
Yamo is...what it is.
I know they get a ton of business, but don't think they need to be that rude. Old lady with the white Afro is a bit obnoxious. Food is good but price is high as hell relative to amount they give you.
Worst service in SF! Maybe even in the whole California!!!
Went to this place last night for the first time. It's absolutely amazing. It's 150% worth it to wait in line. The tea leaf salad didn't sound great but it's insanely good.
Food is amazing, one of the best Burmese place!
I thought this place was only okay but maybe I ordered the wrong things. The tea leaf salad was really good. I'd get it again. It was crispy and flavorful.

Definitely my favorite Burmese spot in town (and around). I've been here twice (visited a few other Burmese spots more than once as well) and can honestly say that the food here is off the hook! Portions on some dishes aren't too big, but the price is just right! You've gotta get the tea leaf salad. Without question, this is my favorite tea leaf salad in the Bay. Their house noodles are super good and the catfish stew is pretty good, if you like catfish.

This place has consistently great food, and consistently surly service. Which is fine by me. I went with the fish chowder and curry beef, neither of which I'd had before. The fish chowder was huge and surprisingly delicious. That may become a regular item for me. The curry beef was good, but I still prefer house noodles with beef and the mango chicken.
if i walk by and one of the seven barstools is open, i go in.

Someone needs to correct the opening time for this store.  It closes at 9pm, NOT 10 pm.  The place is kinda neat.  It reminds me of real ghetto places in China that serves delicious suspicious meat.  It's tasty food, but it's ghetto.  Everything has a slight burnt/charred taste to it.  It may be on purpose or it may be the pans need to be cleanse better.  The tea leaf salad is super small, but it's tasty. The Yamo fried rice and House special cold noodle are nice.  Service ain't great, but I hear customers thanking Ma for dinner.  I'll be back if I want good decent food before 9 pm.

Ok food and long line. For a whole in a wall place, food is not particularly impressive. I think people is more going there for the experience of going to a seemingly authentic place. But as asian myself, I honestly don't get why it is so popular...

I don't know what I can add that hasn't already been said but hot diggity, I'm all about $6 menu items. I may not be a math whiz but I can easily multiple by sixes, yessirree. I've always seen a long line snaking out the door and at 7 pm on a Tuesday, it was a small blessing that only the bar seating was full sans line.

The food is really good! We had a tea leaf salad and a mango salad then topped it all off with a cold noodle dish with chicken. It was fun watching them make the dishes right in front of us. Our bill came to $18 before tip.

The food is pretty good. Nothing amazing. Loaded with MSG. Small portions. Price is good, service sucks. I would suggest going at off times because I don't think this place is worth the wait. I think it's just popular because there's a line. Hipsters and techies love lines. I think there's better Asian food in the neighborhood.
This is how my visit to Yamo went down.
The wait is usually about 30 mins. I always get the:

Great bang for the buck and very fast service, assuming you can get in the door. Although all the main dishes I've had have been too oily, they're always tasty. The ladies who work there are the grumpiest humans ever! But you don't come here to make friends with them. Minus one star for not taking credit and for not having beer.
Never disappointed with food. This is my 2nd takeout. It is literally hole in the wall place. Food is fresh and cheap. Can't wrong house noddles and samusas.

Worst service ever!!! Those ladies treat you like enemies instead of customers. It's really hard to find parking so my bf went to look for parking while I waited in line. Then they told me I have to wait for the other party to come to sit inside. Fine. Since we didn't know how long it would take to get a parking, we changed our mind to order take out. Right after I ordered take out, my bf found a parking and came. There were only 2 ppl dining in at that time. And no one was waiting in the line. Then we asked whether we can change to eat inside. The lady yelled at us "no, you can't change your mind".

This place is one of my favorites! Try the tea leaf salad, house noodles, and mango chicken. Probably the best tea leaf salad in all of San Francisco, IMHO. The ladies who run it are pretty awesome as well, they're all business. I once ordered something like 5 tea leaf salads to pick up for friends, and when I showed up at the restaurant, the ladies made fun of me for ordering so many. It's fantastic. I do think it's better to order food for pickup, since the location is kind of small and smokey. But eating there can be fun too if you have 2 or 3 people. Definitely check it out.

When it comes to Burmese good... These three gals know what's up. Before writing my review- I wanted to read some of the bad reviews... To get a chuckle.. Face it...these three women have to deal with all the assholes the pretentious the crazies the over entitled . You name it. I hear people making reviews about omg it's only 8 seats.. She's mean to me..(hey whatever sometimes I'm afraid to ask for a refill of water)
Food is amazing, one of the best Burmese place! There are couple reasons that I'm take off three stars.

The epitome of hole-in-the-wall deliciousness. Service is efficient; the asian ladies are not super chatty (so don't take it personally), but you will get a delicious meal :) Yamo has one counter with no more than 10 seats for guests, which faces their open kitchen and prep area. It was fun to see the process of our food being cooked, and all the oil that goes into it haha (but that's why it's delicious, so I'm not complaining).

The food was awful! I asked for the fish curry and they ran out. Instead I ordered the tofu curry. It was brown & flavorless. I feel like I'm going to be sick:( also is the price $6. Well I got charged $7. Don't waste your time on this hole in the wall. Yuck!

Great little hole in the wall place in the Mission! I got the Fish Chowder which was really good, but I wish there had been more crunchy pieces. My two friends that I went with are both vegan, and both their tofu dishes were really good as well.
Yeah, she is not here to make you happy. It is what it is and unapologetically so. It's an experience. It's not clean or polite. But it does not pretend to be otherwise.
The house noodles with beef are terrific. Service is minimal, seating is limited with maybe nine seats but this is a terrific place to grab a quick lunch at a very reasonable price.
This place rocks. It's tiny, hot, and loud, but the food is incomparable and the prices are incredibly low.

This place makes me upset that I live on the east coast. The food here is just outstanding. Authentic Burmese dishes at really reasonable prices in a no non sense kitchen is my kind of language. It is really a hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats total but all with a front row seat to the cooking action. I was truly blown away by the tea leaf salad (I don't even know what tea leaves are but they taste great!). Yea it was a small portion but it was $3.50... I've seen places serve a salad that small and charge $10. The house noodles with beef was life changing, as in what do I need to do to eat here everyday for the rest of my life? As I ate each bite I marveled at the texture of the noodles and the flavor of the sauce. The beef was thinly sliced and nicely charred, muy sexy. A very satisfying meal that I hope to enjoy again soon!

If you go out to eat for the customer service, don't eat here obviously. I think a good sign for authentic Asian restaurants is if people complain about customer service. I ordered, the food appeared. The ladies refilled my water glass. I'm happy.

What It's like eating here: The ladies running this joint are at Folsom Street Fair wearing full zentai suits and whipping the Yamo grease out of their customers.  The 'Safety Word' is: "Tea Leaf Salad".  If you are a masochist or like thrown shade, Yamo is the place for you!  One time I saw the staff be unreasonably rude to a sweet pregnant lady, which I'm not cool with.  Another time a friend of mine asked if they were still open and she scowled at him and walked away silently. Tactless.

After being overwhelmed by the club-scene that is Mission Chinese my friend and I opted for Yamo for take out instead. The place is quite literally a hole in the wall, I was certain we had the wrong address until we peeked inside. The ladies behind the counter are serious and curt, but they're busy boiling, frying and tossing dishes with about three inches of counter space in an chili oil sauna, so you really can't blame them. We waited outside for our Yamo House Noodles with Chicken, Egg Rolls (with amazing, homemade sweet and sour sauce), and Pot Stickers. Even after BART-ing home the food was still warm and satisfying. Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but far from the worst.

I agree with people saying about the customer service.  Confirmed!! It sucks!! This place is pretty cheap but you probably have to order 2-3 orders of stuff just to get full so you pay for what u get. The tea leaf salad was good but I think it was like 3 forks full. I was like What???? All you guys that gives this place 4/5 stars?? You guys are freaken high off your ass!!!
Such a small place you could easily miss it. It's worth eating in, but you will probably have to wait due to the shortage of chairs and space.
I have absolutely no idea how this place hasn't been shut down yet.

Old lady was super unfriendly,  She threw my order in  to me and said that I have to go out :) From what I have learned thats their trade mark . Food was tasty but not a lot protein inside :(  It was cheap though.
It's like going to grandma's house to eat, except there are three grandmas and they make great food!
Three words: PORK. BELLY. DONUTS. Also, bottomless mimosas. Ok that's 6 words but it's basically the only 6 words you need to know. The patio is the perfect spot to enjoy these treats from heaven.
Initially I was super apprehensive about this place... Hipster vibe partnered with hipster indie 'journalism'  coverage.

Ended up here while bar hopping on my bday! Such a nice place with red walls, an intimate cosy feeling and just nice people with a sense of humour (guy handing out jell-o shots!). The open bench area at the back was comfortable and fun with a random movie screening over our heads, projected against the wall. Not tried the food here yet but will be back :)

we came here for a yc fellow kind of party.  its def better than a bar in financial district tho its funky smoky or whatever else.   yet its too busy with too many people and sometimes its hard to move around.  music is loud. food is ok.   but all together it gives out a good vibe.

Nice intimate bar with outdoor seating in the back. Great beer selection which includes some rare bottles for sale. Bartender wasn't always great at noticing me, even when the bar was barely active. Other then that, it was great.
Great beer selection. Really decent food. Cool, nice respectful staff. Kick ass hidden patio. No frills.
I liked this place, as do many of the reviewers. But first, a warning.
Great beer, pork dougnuts, and a atmosphere with character...  what more do you need?!
This review is for brunch, and particularly for the chicken and waffles.

It was a really warm day so we tried to get outdoor seating, which was a little challenging. The one vacant spot was in the sun because their umbrella was broken (go figure, that's probably why it was open). It was noon so the sun made it really hot, but it was fine.
The food here is very heavy. I'm pretty sure it's what heartattacks are made of.

Dive bars are fine, except when they're filthy. Seriously, this place needs to get a mop and cleaning rag out. And maybe wash your dish ware. And give your patrons silverware to eat with. Yeeesh. Indifferent staff don't make it better or "cooler" either. I can get a beer anywhere peeps.

At first Sycamore just looks like your average dive bar. Then you get ahold of the menu (featuring goodies like fried mac 'n cheese balls, pork belly donuts, and mix & match sliders) and venture to the back terrace, and it's like a whole new place crackling with possibilities.
mmmmm really tasty. I got the pulled pork sandwich which was delicious. Also a really good spot to hang in SF. Don't be shy to jump in on one of the long shared tables.

Weekend brunch is amazing.  Get the chicken and waffles.  If you decide you want to stop drinking your bottomless mimosa before 3pm, you're going to have to be assertive about it, because the servers don't give up easy.
So - I didn't realize Sycamore was a dive bar before I planned on taking my boyfriend and his parents there for lunch one day.

This place looks like a dive bar and there's surprisingly no line for brunch before noon. I got a veggie scramble, which was nothing too special. The pork belly doughnuts were good and interesting, but not something I'd order again. So, why am I giving this place 4 stars?
I feel like if it were 1960 this is the place where a bunch of kids would get together to later go on and form either an amazing rock band, fashion a Dead Poets Society, or start a cult.
Yay! I'm a fan!

SO GOOD! went on saturday at about noon for bottomless mimosas and breakfast. i got 2 sliders with fried egg and bacon, which were a little dry but delisih, fries, and bottomless for 24 bucks! not too shabby... and the waitress was veryyyyy attentive with refilling the mimosas. prime.

I don't really write reviews but this place was awesome. We had bottomless mimosas (no brainer), chicken and waffles (really good), roast beef sandwich (little spicy kick which was great), and biscuits and gravy with 2 fried eggs (really good). It's small and only have beer and wine but the workers here are amazing.

The Sycamore is a really fascinating place. At first, it seems like a bit of a dive bar in the middle of a bustling and somewhat dirty section of the mission. There's only very limited seating in front and a tiny bar serving a selection of craft brews. It doesn't really seem like a place where you would want to eat brunch. However, you'd be doing yourself a disservice if you skipped the breakfast fare.
Wait, I haven't reviewed this yet?  Pork belly donuts!  On two trips, they've been fattier and more flavorful (yay rock salt!) than the ones at the Willows.  And their lamb sliders are solid too.
Great roast beef sammie and super tasty fries. I loved the hoppy ale they recommended. $16 was the total bill. Make sure to check out the back patio.
jenn is amazing!! "the domer" - she kept us happy and our glasses full!! love this place!!!

the sycamore is a great place to go for lunch. HUGE fan of the roast beef sandwich and a beer on tap called HOLYCRAFT - MAGNUM OPUS. The roast beef sandwich is juicy and the barbeque sauce and horseradish mayo is superb, wash it all down with this Belgium Style HOLYCRAFT MAGNUM OPUS and your taste buds will be craving it for weeks to come. My friend had the Burger and we shared the chicken sliders as well. All extremely tasty.
I have long loved their beer selection but damn this place has some seriously delicious brunch!

Was visiting SF for the weekend and a native friend brought us here so we could start out day rage. Bottomless mimosas were ordered and refills came often. Got the pork belly doughnuts, were good but not what I was expecting at all. Also had some sliders, which I found to be only mediocre. Cool vibes and the place is a lil small but there is outdoor seating available in the back. Was caught playing drinking games with the mimosas.. Shame on me.
Yum! This place was small and delightful... Bottomless mimosas, pork belly donuts, and tasty egg scrambles.  seating is limited....

Before I get into my review, I'm just going to rave about the Mimosa Madam. Or Mistress, whatever she prefers. But she was on top of her game. We've done a few bottomless mimosas, and this is the only place where your glass will be half empty and BAM, full again. We lost count of how many we had had, because she was there - and for the whole patio, too. Later we saw her running to pick up more OJ, but damn if this woman doesn't deserve a liver-shaped award and a raise.

Pretty sweet dive bar with legit beer selection. My partner and I happened by this place while in the neighborhood and stopped by for an afternoon drink.
