Ok, so it is not that this place is very bad ... In fact, if Picaro was not at 5 minutes walking, you could really go here. But I sadly don't see the reason. Sorry, guys. Kill the Picaro's staff ...

OMG. You have to take your friends here. Cheap cover, live salsa, people who know how to dance and drinks that will knock you out before you finish your second round. The place is so much fun after 10ish. Granted you will be paying a good 10 dollars a drink but you will be getting your money's worth. Try an AMF and you won't regret it. The bouncer was really nice to literally pick up a table and bring it right to us. Now that's service! The bartender is quick and never leaves you waiting. The place has been around for decades so it's got history. Always gets packed by the end of the night so arrive before 11 if you are going to get a table. Now that's salsa.
They give you a lot of food, but it is not great.

Never tried it but it seems busy every time I passed by it going to BART in the late afternoon.Its not like Panda Express with different trays on a steamer but its look like a Cantonese type foods on steamer like sweet and sour pork, pork fried rice, chow mein. I was checking the yelp on it before I would tried it. I guess the people who are buying the food to go or to eat in just don't yelp. I don't think they have a liquor license. I might tried it brown bag (plastic bag) it to work. I am giving it 2 stars for the location and the workers I see them working with a smile.
Yes, 5 star only because it cures TBs sweet tooth, where we get our donut fix.
Same review as the other China Express: "It's not the best quality Chinese food, but it is 6 bucks for a meal!  Probably wins the crown for cheapest dinner in the Mission..."
If you know chinese food, then this is the place to go! There are very reasonable prices.

This place was dirty  but wat do u expect from a chinese fast food restaurant on mission street. i have been here multiple times and the thing that keeps me coming back is their combo meal. I always order chow mein, hot chicken wings, brocolli and beef, and sometimes teriyaki chicken. If your in a rush and you happen to be in the neighborhood, stop by. Their workers are very friendly but watch out for the people who ask for money and for ur leftovers.

I feel so guilty that I can actually write a review of this place, and I feel even worse that I've eaten here more than once!  The food here is bad and of the lowest quality you can find.  But what do you expect of a Chinese restaurant on Mission and 24th?  Everything is really greasy, and anything that is breaded and deep fried (e.g. orange chicken, sweet and sour pork, etc.) is 95% breading and 3% mystery meat (I don't know where the other 2% belongs).  The diners are pretty scary and dirty, and there are usually pigeons wandering in from the sidewalk.
Julie's hot dog cart was parked near 24th & mission. menu is bacon dogs, chips, soda, burgers....
It's a bacon wrapped dog.
If it's anything out of the ordinary that I can't get elsewhere or if it's bacon, it's gonna get in mah bellyyy. Yums ;)

If I could give them zero stars I would. Their hot dog cart was set up below my bedroom window at 11:30 on a Sunday night and the two people running it were chatting non stop. I asked them if they could be quieter and they rudely asked told me that it wasn't as if they could use sign language with their patrons. They didn't have any patrons. They were just conversing with each other.

This is a fair hot dog for late night eating.  It's fairly priced, and they have bottled coke.  There is nothing outstanding about it, and this is the same bacon wrapped hot dog that somehow became famously known as a mission dog.  Huh?  Look, if you are hungry, go for it.  They take cards, too, and are super friendly and I'm sure they do well.  But if you are thinking of making a special trip of it, think again.  The bacon and dog are overdone and not flavorful enough, the jalepenos are mild at best, and the best part of the while ordeal is the grilled onions.  It's just not drool-worthy street meat.
The guys working here are awesome and when you're hangry and need a little something... this place gets the job done!
We got a social coupon here (PinchIt), and decided to try it. If it weren't for the coupon, we probably wouldn't have eaten here because it was SO difficult to order.

Just received a delivery where everything BUT the spaghetti is covered in a watery red sauce. And I thought the delivery man was just in a hurry when he ran away so fast. Now I realize he was just in a hurry to get away before I could yell at him. Pale, bland pasta and soggy sandwich and fries.

This was a great random find.  Truth be told it's not the most attractive facade but the sign for Banh Mi got my wheels turning and a quick Yelp confirmed that his book was not to be judged by it's cover.
One of my favorite grocery store in the mission!

Duc Loi is my go-to Asian market when I need Thai basil -- they always have Thai basil and thai chillies when all the other asian markets are sold out.  They also have a large produce section, however, the prices aren't that great, and freshness is only so-so.

I went here for lunch for banh mi, I tried to buy the last bottle of a yuzu kombucha drink, but they couldn't find a price so they wouldn't sell it to me.  The nice older owner of the market felt bad and brought me a free Vietnamese coffee (not orderable)

The day before Labor Day (8/31/2014), I was visiting a friend who lives in the Mission.  Neighbors around were grilling and it smelled so good, we decided to find a nearby market and get a steak to grill.  When we got in the market, I noticed the produce was very expensive, but we did buy 2 corn cobs and 2 potatoes.  When we got to the meat counter, the 4 pieces of beef steak were huge and thick.  We chose the best of the 4, but I noticed when the clerk picked up the beef, her fingernails looked grey.  We ended up spending $25 just for the steak (overpriced I thought).  The grilled meat did take good, not the best, but OK.  However, now I think I have a parasite as I have been sick for a week.  I've been nauseous, have barely eaten the past week and when I do, I have terrible heartburn, and have to force myself to vomit, plus I had excessive diarrhea.  Yesterday (Sunday), a week after eating the grilled steak, I went to the bathroom 8 times within 2 hours.   Along with all the vomiting and nausea, belching and gas, my stomach is excessively bloated.

I really do actually like this place. The people are nice and they have a good variety of random stuff; healthy, unhealthy, organic, not organic, local and totally not... I was totally amused (and bemused) one time, when I saw them broadcasting a video promoting their Harris Ranch selection. It featured lovely green rolling hill pastures, with a happy farmer behind an old style cattle pull tiller. I couldn't turn away! If anyone here doesn't know Harris Ranch, go and take a lovely and tedious drive up the 5... You'll know when you get there... BUT! This is not about that, this is about the produce section. Seriously... They reeeeealllly need to pay more attention to the produce section. I worked in produce, I could totally help out. The first step is, cull the old shit out... Seriously... You can not sell moldy and disintegrating produce... Never.... They are trying to, but they can not, ever, never.  Stop it. Stop it now.

Duc Loi has been around since the 80s, you know, during the days of Charlie's Angels, Bionic Woman, and The Knight Rider!  They have remodeled several times but one thing that hasn't changed, their banh mi remains good.  They give you enough portion to make you keep coming back.  It gets busy here during lunch time.
Don't know what the big deal is on reviews about this place. The prices are high compared to so many other markets in the neighbourhood.
Best grocery.  Organic and amazing brands.

I came to Duc Loi Supermarket, which bills itself as a "Vietnamese" market, in search of Vietnamese ingredients to cook Vietnamese food at home. Instead, I discovered a market that's more Mexican than Vietnamese, devoid of some of the most basic Vietnamese ingredients (like "cuon" rice noodles, "rau" Vietnamese greens). I suppose I should have known better, given that the location is in the mission. The only really Vietnamese thing about this market is that they make "banh mi" Vietnamese sandwiches in the deli area that are pretty good, though somewhat overpriced. Otherwise, only shop here if you are interested in preparing a Mexican dinner at home or perusing their yuppie selection of wines and liquors.
The mile long produce aisle has a selection from all over the world.  Great mix of cheap and organic.  Definitely the highlight.

DLW did some Interweb searches in preparation for our vacation in SF, and came across a YouTube video touting this place. She is a big fan of Asian markets in general, and I am a big fan of banh mi in general, so we made a point of finding this place on our tourist map. Armed with our Muni bus passes we headed into the Mission District.

The Vietnamese sandwiches are indeed the best bargain around. This market has been steadily improving since re-opening. Produce is moving more towards organic, and they have a lot of nice imported and specialty foods in all departments. They really listen when given sincere suggestions from customers. A hard working family run place. The house made Kale salad is really delicious. They've been selling out lately, it's that good! The Kimchee is also very delicious. They have an excellent selection of lower priced wines.

Been living nearby for over a year now and they are solid for convenience but the general grocery quality is low,  the prices are very high and the place just feels a bit dirty. I still will come here for a quick grab for a snack or beer but if you want to get real groceries, I would recommend somewhere else

This store doesn't have a great selection, but it's conveniently located if you're looking for Asian groceries and don't want to go to the sunset/Richmond. It's never struck me as particularly clean so I avoid the prepared foods. Great selection of produce and meat.

Was walking past here to dinner one time and came across this place. Since it was closed at the moment, I made a mental note (and a bookmark on yelp) to come back later! I prefer to buy my groceries at Trader Joes but decided to come here to pick up some Asian goodies that are not available at TJs.

Items priced at $1 more or even double that of neighbouring grocery stores, which when you're buying a variety of different vegetables/herbs adds up to quite a bit. A small handful of hard-to-find Asian items, otherwise shop elsewhere. Attitude behind the meat counter if you want something cut is miserable.
Five stars hands down. Where else can you buy fresh tortillas, mung bean mochi, and gluten free cookies all in one place?  The organic foods are cheaper than whole foods and rainbow.  Total win!
Love my neighborhood grocer.  Took about 6 months to a year to ween off of Safeway but glad I did.
The perfect one stop grocery. Half ranch 99, half whole foods, and half Mexican market. Great variety of Asian and Mexican food stuffs as well as organic snack options.
+ cheap

This is the closest market to my apartment and I just love it. It has a lot of speciality, hard to find foods, and lots of basic staples too. Some items are pricier here, as it is a local convenience store, but I have found that some items are cheaper here than they are at big chains like Safeway. I tend to not shop here much for fruit and vegetables, honestly bc I don't care much if a food is organic or not, and Ranchito market is right down the street and cheaper. But the organic section is one of the few I have seen in this neighborhood, definite plus of that's your thing.  All the staff here is very nice and very helpful. I eat a Vietnamese sandwich from here at least once a week, these are so good. And so cheap. I have brought friends here for lunch and have brought these sandwiches to go to visit with friends and family. I now get specific requests for these sandwiches.
You get what you pay for, well sort of.
Best Vietnamese banh mi sandwiches in the Mission (and in SF, IMHO but that's for another review). The deli sandwiches are awesome and the ladies behind the counter are so nice!
Sometimes I come here solely due to convenience.

Great all-around neighborhood grocery store. Everything from fancy cheeses to weird Japanese curry mixes and a nice assortment of organic and non-organic in the produce section. (I try to buy organic, but you know, sometimes I still get sticker shock, especially at Bi-Rite.) It's also pretty balanced between Anglo, Latino, and Asian specialty foods. It feels like a grocery store where everyone is welcome. The owner, who works behind the sandwich counter, is really nice, too. She seems to know a lot of people personally and I've seen her giving out dinner to the neighborhood on Thanksgiving. Sometimes the bananas seem not so fresh, but that's about the worst thing I can say.

Good tofu and portobello Bahn Mi! The tour was grilled and seasoned right. The portobello mushroom cooked nice and well.  The favored was good without the mayo. Get it without the mayo, you aren't missing anything.

This supermarket is stocked with fresh veggies, organic produce, and a variety of your Asian fundamentals - from Sriracha to Vietnamese fish sauce! Since I cook with pretty specific Asian sauces, there are a couple I know they don't sell (e.g. light soy sauce, some Indian spices) but for the most part they have everything. I was pleasantly surprised that they sold premium beers, cheeses, and even my favorite tofu noodles!
Duc Loi knows its customer, but since the mission is such an eclectic place to live, that makes for a fairly eclectic selection.

Im sad I missed the running of the  Mission Street Food Burger here. However having dinner nearby, I decided to plop in and see why Anthony Myint would server a burger out of a market. I guess they already have a sandwich biz inside so why not put the burger on their. Lots of cool interesting imported Asian products. Some really unusual things as well. You need Kewpie Mayo? Or Korean Ssam Jang Paste? Maybe it's Nutella or Point Reyes Blue Cheese? Pretty crazy culmination of products, not just of the Asian variety. It's like a deranged Benetton ad.

Amanda, the owner, told me a story about fleeing Vietnam by boat in the 80s and having to subsist on a daily ration of a tablespoon of cooked rice. This is the reason she sometimes kept fruit and veggies past their prime, she said, as she loaded me up with bunches of bananas, drastically reduced because they had a few brown spots.

I love Duc Loi! Having a decent Asian market in the Mission is so great. Fresh curry leaves, Thai basil and exotics fruits to choose from. Pork belly and Korean short ribs! Lots of noodles and chili sauces. And the staff is always friendly and helpful.

Transport yourself to a hardcore Asian supermarket right here in San Francisco and visit Duc Loi Supermarket.  Be prepared to open your eyes and check-out all possible objects that you can potentially wolf-down.  A lot of vegan sneaky suprises.  Grab a durian, or other exotic tropical fruits found nowhere else.  Paint your own culinary spectrum of expericnce.  Look around and see how you are transported to a wormhole into a culture.
Cheap. Fresh. Organic. Huge Variety of hard to find ingredients.
Key words: Organic. Variety. Friendly.

I had the delight of discovering this little gem last week. I tried a Vietnamese sandwich for the first time, on recommendation of the wonderfully friendly lady behind the meat counter. She went out of her way to make it special for me, explaining tradition as she worked. For any amount of money, it was by far the greatest sandwich I've ever eaten. For five dollars!!! I'll make a special trip to return there. Been thinking about it every day since :))) fabulous flavors and oh so fresh !!
Some days, you're left debating between a pizza or Chinese. Pasta or a burrito? Thai or a burger? You just can't seem to decide; better yet, you're so hungry, you just don't care.

I just like this market. I can't help it. It's not even that close to my home, but when I find myself dawdling on Mission (which I find myself doing after digesting a belly-stretching burrito), I somehow end up here thinking I should get something healthy or at least ethnic. That motivation may come from the fact that it feels like such a global community in here spanning Asia and Latin America when it comes to its packaged and canned foods. It also offers the lure of organic produce, Niman Ranch meats, and Mary's Free Range poultry. You really can't go wrong with that eclectic mix of groceries in a paper bag emblazoned with the slogan, "Go Green! Go Organic!"
A wide selection of hard to find items (ethnic sauces, random brands etc...)

Amazing quality and cost for organic produce, high quality meat, and vast variety of different ethnic foods (dumplings, spices, vinegars). Also a nice bunch of inexpensive wine. I always go here before I go to Bi-Rite, because they often have the same stuff for way cheaper.

Ghetto place definitely, but other than that pretty decent for fast food chain.  I'm glad their health score is 91/100 for a crampy small crowded dinky franchise.  Tuesdays the deal is great... you get a full meal for a few bucks and all that meat.. but always a line for the cheapy days.  Chicken are fresh cooked on those days because it's constant people ordering.  Poor chickens ... they probably hate Tuesdays now.

It's fast food and it's Popeyes so there's not much to say anything grand about this place. The food is good and pretty much the usual taste. Got some tenders and biscuits here. My normal and usual orders every time I go here. The service from this one is good, unlike the previous joint I went to. Good place to grab a quick grub, is what I like to say as a summary.
Popeye's has been a semi-favorite over the years. not so much now. my tastes have evolved. usual menu. small counter for ordering. just a few tables for sitdown

Although I grew up on KFC chicken because of their seasoning flavor, I highly prefer Popeye's based on the crunchiness of their chickens. The best time to go to this place would be any day that is not Tuesday or very early when they open. But then you'll end up paying more since Tuesday is 2 pc for $1.29 which is an awesome deal. The only catch is that you'll be stuck in line that goes all the way around the block. They're service is quick but the only thing that needs improvement would be the politeness of their staff. I don't know if it's the lack of their English skills or the stress that douche bags and hood rats bring into the store that makes them bitchy, but I hope they work on it...

This place is dangerously close to our office. When we open the doors on the balcony, we can smell the chicken cooking. One day at lunch time, 10 separate staff members came back with Popeyes. This was not planned, but the smell enticed us.

I love their fried chicken a lot more KFC.  Their seafood is also a must eat.  The only thing bad about the place is that the tables are almost always full.  The Surf and Turf Combo is the best.  LOUISIANA RIGHT!
This is some of the best fried chicken I ever had.
Tasty fried chicken. Cheep and cheerful. What else can you say?
Caucasians , Don't Eat Legs and Thighs, your coupons only have Deals on Dark Meat, wtf's We will continue to Pass...

The manager of this location is SO RUDE. My boss brought us lunch yesterday and when he returned he realized that he had left his phone at the Popeyes. When I called, I asked if they had a lost and found. He just said 'NO.' When I asked if he could ask anyone working yesterday if they saw a phone, he said 'NO.' When I asked if he was serious and asked if there was anyone I could talk to, he hung up on me. I called back and asked for the manager, and he said 'I am the manager', and proceeded to hang up on me again when I tried to ask my question.

I have stopped in here many a time just to grab one of their amazing biscuits.  Scoff all you want, but damn they make some awesome biscuits.  The chicken and other food is actually pretty good at Popeye's too so if you are in need of something quick and cheap that isn't a burrito or bacon-wrapped hot dog, hop in here!
There is nothing quite as delicious as Popeyes chicken. Came here while walking to BART the other day, and couldn't resist stopping in. There was no line, and the staff was friendly.

Rarely visit this place due to the filth inside. This place could be kept clean if they had enough employees to keep up with the messes. With adequate ventilation they could keep the front doors closed (no more pigeons!!). Unlike Pollo Campero down the street where they have security to keep the place clean and safe, Popeye's corporation obviously spends as little as possible. I feel sorry for many of the customers who can't go elsewhere and have to put up with this. The community deserves better.
Poor ingredients and location. Won't be returning.

I strongly dislike this location.  The inside is so small, and the seating is so awkwardly cramped.  I came here on a Tuesday night with the GF.  We got two 2 piece specials, mashed potatoes, and cajun fries.  We wanted spicy and the cashier told us it would be a ten minute wait.  There were two tables that were available.  They were both extremely dirty, with crumbs on the tables, as well as food particles stuck in between the wood of the bench.  I wanted to wash my hands, but of course the restroom and back tables were sectioned off.  This has to be a hazard not only to customers, but to the employees as well.  Just because you are eager to get off work, does not give you the right to block off those tables and the restroom.  That is terrible customer service mentality and you should be penalized for that.
Yep. It's true. Your eyes aren't crossed. You aren't drunk or dreaming.
Love their Fry Chicken Crispy Skin, Moist Meat and Season with flavor kick. Yummy Cajun Fries and Dessert Mississipi Mud Cake.
I have had the worst experience with dining at this popeyes location ... and it could have possibly prevented me from ever returning again!
WARNING!...AVOID!

Came here for a Tuesday special since I have class around the corner at CCSF. Ordered a order of leg and thigh that was spicy but I would say the two pieces of spicy was pretty brunt and I should of took my friends tip on not ordering spicy at this location. The service here seems to be faster than the Geneva location because I got my order right as I paid. I also noticed some of the employees here also work at the Geneva location.

I enjoy Popeye's sometimes when im in mood 4 it and others not so much. But today I was with a friend who wanted some Popeye's twenty minutes came two aggressive pandlehandlers walk in starting asking for money the first one is a well dressed African American man stating that he is homeless Yeah right homeless my butt he ask everyone who came in and second was a cauasian woman who was on crack started to make sound she left and came back and sit down for thirty second and got up and went to the counter and cause a scene with the manager there. I thought it was funny but sad how people can come in cause a scene or demand money from hard working folk because they can.

I came here for their Tuesday $1.29 for two pieces special, with orders taken for coworkers. I was bracing for a long line like that I've seen at the Geneva and Mission location whenever I drive by there on a Tuesday, but to my pleasant surprise there wasn't any. In fact during the whole time I was there the longest it ever got was only three or four deep.

I'm biased, cause I love popeyes everywhere - but the one on Mission is dope. Their Tuesday special is unbeatable, and the perfect snack. Pretty much go there every week, but make sure you go when the chill Chinese lady is working, she hooks it up with 2-thighs for the special. Luhhhhhh that chicken from Popeyes

I've had the fancy fried chicken at Town Hall, Front Porch and the likes but honestly the chicken here is just as good for 1/10th of the price.  I actually walked by last Tues when they had their $1.29 leg/thigh special going and got an order to stay.  Yep, I hunkered down in the joint with the real people and put down the pipping hot spicy goodness right there.  It was delicious, not one complaint.  Probably not a good place to form any regular habits of eating, but when the fried chicken hankering sets in, this is the place.

The most unappealing part of this place is the fact that EVERY visit here, I encounter pigeons inside the restaurant. If we were dining outside, this would be acceptable. However, this is NOT acceptable to have pigeons flying around inside while I'm trying to eat.

It was a Tuesday around 4pm as I was heading home on MUNI when I decided that some fried chicken (and red beans and rice) would hit the spot.  The Popeyes line was long, stretching out the front door onto the sidewalk becuz they run a 99 cent 2-piece deal on Tuesdays.  There was a host of kooky characters in the restaurant (some with a handful of loose change) waiting to order or awaiting their meal, including a lady who either had Tourette Syndrome or was slightly battered herself.  She let out a coo-caw-caw sound at the top of her lungs and to my surprise, very few people even seemed to notice.  I tried to stifle my laughter, while a small child further back in line began egging her on to "do it again, do it again" (so she did).  OK, so much for the floor show, I got my 8-piece to go and headed out.

Hate to admit it, but I love Popeye's chicken.  The place is "earthy", but damn well worth it.  Somewhere along the line fried chicken became popular and a handful of trendy places (Farmer Brown, Front Porch, Brenda's, Good Friggn Chicken) offer fried chicken, but at a premium price.  If you just want some tasty chicken, at a cheap price, and fast, this is the spot.

I tell my friends about all the delicious food in the Mission, but somehow I find myself at Popeyes almost every week. Now that they've been forced by law to list calories you can figure out the best bang for buck while you're waiting.

This the Popeyes restaurant I go to from time to time. I've been here once or twice last year and several times this year. Spring semester 2010 & 2011, I went to Mission Campus for English 96 & 1B. I make a pit stop for some food as I am heading to school. Students heading up the block to go to class at CCSF Mission Campus would come here for a quick grub.
URGENT UPDATE: Still delicious.  Still dirt cheap.

I've been coming here since I was like 8, I'm 19 now, and I still come here when I have time or just in town. The chicken is marinated right, service is as fast as they can, no one slacks off. Bathroom requires a token, but that's understandable being in the Mission District. There's a self serve soda machine, YAY!!! Bathroom is unclean just because there is not enough time to clean it, so don't use it unless you have to, it's filled with Graffiti too, damn uneducated people. Ask for wet naps, they usually have them. No parking though and it's usually crowded and people come in panhandling too. I once gave this guy 3 pennies into his cup and he threw it out, what a idiot, if everyone in the mission district gave him 3 cents everyday he'd be at least middle-class
I love me some chicken!   Fried chicken + cajun fries + orange Fanta.  Every time I eat there, I envision myself singing this song...

This is the largest location of the 4 stores in SF (outside the city, the San Bruno location is larger), but not as clean or popular as the Divisadero store. Except on Tuesdays when people line up for the 99 cents 2-piece leg and thigh meal. Daytime parking is relatively easy, but nearly impossible during evenings.

Have you ever heard of Popeyes chicken it's pretty good. Tastes pretty good. My favorite is the chicken it's pretty good. Number one mashed potatoes number two is macaroni three is corn on cob bone four is the ranch sauce.

I wanted some fried chicken so my boyfriend drove all the way from Oakland to this Popeyes . The fried chicken and biscuts here are pretty good . But what really impressed me was their mashed potatoes with gravy . It was very smooth and yummy . Just thinking about the gravy is making my mouth water ! I've been to Popeyes in SF but I think that this location is the best location ... it has the best tasting food .

this review is for the fried chicken alone, because that's the only thing you need to know.  i don't know how they do it, but it is utterly fucking delicious.  colonel sanders has never had popeyes because he'd be saying that popeye's is finger lickin good instead.  I have to order only 2 or 3 pieces at a time because I can eat 12 pieces in one sitting like a one man family...then my sexy will hate me
For all of you who like cheap chicken, watch this video on Youtube:

I avoid fast-food for the most part, but I'll break that rule in a pinch.  I had been to Popeye's before (other locations, a couple of years ago) and always enjoyed the food.  For fast-food chicken, it didn't get much better.  My opinion has since changed.

Today I ordered the # 7 5 piece chicken strip and mashed potatoes and nasty ass gravy and biscuit. I asked young lady at counter for some sauce. I asked what sauce they had she hella mumble something and Ranch. I said what!!!.

I would take the 29 Sunset at Balboa Park Station and there will always be someone on the bus with Popeyes.  There is a shop over by Geneva and Mission.  The bus will reek of that special scent of fried chicken--that strong, tempting scent.  I would say to myself, "Damn, someone must have Popeyes."  I look around to see who the culprit is and give them the look.  Well, that happened a couple of times, probably around ten.  Today, I finally gave in and stopped by the one by Mission and 22nd since I was in the area (BART Delay).

This is the best place for cheap but good hole in the wall Chinese food outside of Chinatown and the Chinese Chinatown (i.e. Richmond district). I live in the Potrero neighborhood, so to have this gem pretty close to the house is amazing. Everything is good. I don't know why other reviews are low.

I love this place!!! :-) The food is hot, fresh, and comes in nice portions. I really like the Mongolian beef and korean chicken. So much flavor. The people that work there are really busy but very nice. Makes all the difference! I will keep coming back.

Omg I'm sick with a high fever so I decided to come here to get some chicken wonton & lemon chicken... 1st i was rushed while lookin at the menu & the wait was almost over 30mins.. When I got home to eat I was disgusted to find little plastic wraps in my soup & now sacred to try the lemon chicken.
Order for pick up and got 3 out of 4 orders wrong. On top of that I had to pay extra. Food is super greasy and bland. The service definitely sucks and waited nearly 45 minutes!
I made an order for pick up and got there in 20 min. The food was all ready to go, pretty fast service.

This place is the most American of American chinese food joints. Meat is tenderized beyond comprehension. Sauces are thick. Noodles are too soft. Broths are one note. They also seem severely understaffed. Probably won't be coming back.

Told us takeout would be ready in 10-15 min. We showed up after 20 min and they hadn't started making it yet. They would not give us a discount, nor would they deliver (we proposed leaving & have them deliver it when ready).

I love this place! A friend of mine went here today and i was telling him that i pass this place almost on a daily basis but never really paid attention to it because it's part hidden and right next to a produce market + it looks quite dingy from the outside. A typical Chinese greasy food place but really good chow if you're in a hurry and a No Nonsense service. their prices are bit on the pricey side but since this place is been in this spot for the longest time more than i could even remember, you know you need to make a profit knowing this place is good and it's been here that long. My friend ordered a large hot bowl of won ton soup and when it came it was the size of a toilet bowl...I nearly fell off my seat because i cannot believe what i'm seeing how big that bowl of soup is! Me my friend and probably 2 more other people could eat this soup bowl and would still be full. i ordered a Beef w/ scrambled eggs over rice and it was it when it came in even though this wasn't in the menu.My friend told me that these people will actually cook anything you want, just describe it what it would look like when it's cooked and they get it right. I think i now have my NEW old standby place and this is basically 30 yards from the 16th Street BART station right next to the Burger King. This place accepts PLASTICS (Debit & Credit cards) w/c is a big plus for me & the 2 girls serving you is excellent but always in a hurry but their service is great and they never complained.Expect to wait a bit when it's lunchtime and their menu is substantial. Vey good chow and the service is excellent & no complaints here, i would mind going to the city just for this riding my bicycle because it's so easy & accessible...
Too much MSG in the soup!! Even if it's free, I wouldn't recommend drinking it.

Great lunch spot!  They have a huge lunch special menu, food is decent and they're quick. I love their complimentary corn soup.  I also love their beef scrambled egg over rice (I've only seen the shrimp option available at other restaurants).  I've also tried their wonton soup, chow fun, sweet and sour fish and so far so good.
Food taste good!, Big Portion & cheap! Don't let the look of the place fool you. Their daily special is a bargain too. This place seems busy during lunch time (mostly regulars).
Not a vegetarian friendly place, just like many other Chinese restaurants out there. The portion is really huge. Food is okay. Waitresses are nice and fast.

In a very spur of the moment decision, my boyfriend decided that we should get a roast duck for Christmas Eve dinner. We had been walking around in the Mission, and a quick Yelp search reveals this place. They have roast duck. We order some spicy green beans and rice to go with it, and they also give us complimentary corn soup. We take it all to go.
Your sterotypical cheap Asian place.

My boss and I were gossiping about good food. He told me that this Hunan restaurant on 16th and Mission makes good food with big portions at an affordable price. "Conversation like what we had is another way to make you hungry!"

I live just around the corner from Mission Hunan. - very fortunate!  There are many things not on the English menu.  I've tried them by asking for them and by looking at what the Chinese work crews order at lunchtime and pointing.  I LOVE the beef stew clay pot.  I always ask for extra tendon.  If you're not familiar with "beef stew" at Chinese restaurants, it refers to the cut of meat - namely chuck and beef tendon - yummy!  They will combine any ingredients you ask for.  I like lop chong (Chinese sausage) and scrambled eggs.  I like bitter melon and beef stew.  I like the moo-qua (my spelling) with garlic sauce.  You won't find these on the menu.  The only thing they wouldn't make for me is pork fat back and oyster clay pot.  I have to be content with the roast pork and oyster pot - it is delicious.  The only way to get the fat back is with mustard greens.  They also have "Chinese soup" everyday as well as the soup of the day.  Try it on a day when it's tender greens - excellent!  One of their soups du jour is beef vegetable.  This soooo good!   I also get an extra order to go.  Love the Mongolian chicken as well.  Try it.

Huge portions, decent food, and cheap. So I'm a fan. Some of my favs are: salt and pepper pork, mongolian beef, and braised eggplant. They're all really good! One thing I'll never get again and that you should never, EVER order is their beef stew clay pot. It was basically huge chunks of fat and cow veins. Yes, it was as disgusting as it sounds. Everything else we've had has been a winner though.
3.5 stars

Hole in the wall, good food, not the best I've had...the orange chicken was ok, I was bummed.  Not the place for me, but definitely give it a try.  The tank of fish definitely threw me off, but was cool!

As a restaurant, the food is good and cheap. What separates this from Red Jade and Big Lantern (which just reopened on 16th street) is that it seems a bit more authentic. It has a large following of actual Chinese customers, which i find to be a rarity in authenticity. A large percentage of their deals are written in Chinese on pieces of paper on the walls and not in the menu. The food is cheap and the staff is friendly, even as they are rushing around the room.
great hole in the wall - amazing service for what it is, TRY THE SALTED PORKCHOPS - very very very very good.
Mission's best kept secret, a seemingly dumpy Chinese joint right next to a Burger King right off 16th St. BART.
Rating them here relative to other Chinese places.

This place is great! Right next to BART, and super authentic. We were in a group of 8 and ordered family sized portions of fried rice, chow mein, lemon chicken, and Mongolian beef. I ended up taking 3 boxes of leftovers home. The food was served quickly and tasted amazing. With all that, some soup, and drinks all around, the bill was only $60!
Yum!

No stars. I waited (foolishly) a half an hour for togo egg rolls and a large white rice. I heard the woman tell at the kitchen before I asked so I think it was the kitchens fault for putting my order behind those who were dining in, even though I had been there before them.
Came here for lunch today with some coworkers since we were all craving some delicious Chinese food.  Did not disappoint at all!
After checking out the reviews here, I decided to give this place a shot. It seems the lower-rated reviews were the ones that were more accurate.
Their lunch special serve both rice and soup!
The food was good (but not great). The portions were good, service was great, and the prices are really reasonable. It's a good neighborhood Chinese spot. Nothing more.

I love comming here, this is also one of my moms favorite places to go too.. there portions are great for little amount of money.. This is one of the main places we come to if we want Chineese. Love there soups, LOVE the Seafood Wonton soup, and combination Won Ton, we always get the Chicken Vegitables, and steamed rice.. Oh, another thing, there rice. a Small, is litterally the size of your soup bowl.. a mediem, will sometimes look like a Large, and .. well we never order a Large, since were never that many people.. Though, if you plan on going on your own, becaureful, because they do serve a LOT of food on one plate, theres no changing the size of the plate-- "One size only".. I go there once in a while for lunch, I've ordered a Chowmein with Chicken Fried rice, I felt that the plate was big enough for 2 people.. maybe 3.. but it was only $8.75. Not bad right? I guess you can always save the rest for dinner, or your tomorrows lunch. I've recently tried there Sweet & Sour Tilapia, and it's really good, my new favorite. though I think I'd like the Tilapia without the Sweet & Sour sauce, it's a little too sweet for me, and sticky.. but its good.. They have your basic sodas; coke, sprite, orange, etc, Snapple, if you want water, it's better to order the cup of water with ice, because they charge you for a bottled water, they have your basic beer, Coronas, Heniken, Tecate(I think?) etc. for about $3..
The golden rule of being under $10 and satisfying can be observed here. Healthier than Bugger King next door. Also, no yups or hips. Real.
"The soup is wonderful" and it's a bowl, not just a cup! Very fresh ingredients and most importantly, the staff is wonderful!

This place is good. Your typical Chinese fare. Not wonderful but it is down the street from my work. The portions are large, service is fast, inexpensive and always good quality. Good for a quick Chinese fix at lunch!
Alright so I gotta admit, I was skeptical coming here. This area of SF definitely kind of creeped me out. This was one of the few places we saw on yelp that was cheap with decent reviews.
Excellent quality chineese food. I am eating a  chicken brockley rice plate.  Very flavorfull, good portions, fresh and cheap. Don't let the the location keep you away (16th @ capp).
Bleh - not bad if you're despirate for some Chinese food. I'd rather save my money and go somewhere else.
authentic chinese food to satisfy those cravings!
I was very pleasantly surprised with this place! I had thought "Chinese restaurant on the Mission? Mehhhhhhh." But it turned out to be pretty good stuff!
I really love this little place. This place epitomizes small, family owned, hole in the wall resturant with delicious food. Everything is super greasy but it only adds to the flavor.

Super nice owners, and they label how much things cost. Most liquor stores surprise you with a high-value but in this case I could just easily go in and find out what I wanted and pay for it and know the exact amount of money.

If you are looking for special price ;) you have to visit M & C market they have all the special drink .  The best selection Wine , beer , liquor  , and the best selection of the ice cream They are open every day .
Sketchy grocery store on Valencia
Rarely do I find a need to leave a review for something like a corner store. But this place provides such a pleasant shopping experience continuously that I just had to share!

Walking by, you might think this is just some ordinary corner store. Wrong. The prices rival wholesale (I've seen Bulleit and Makers there for $20, unreal). Say hi to Moses, who is probably the friendliest and hardest working person I've ever met. If you pop in on a Friday/Saturday, there's a good chance that there will be lasers and dance music blasting.
Happiness is...
they sold me a case of Four Loko before the original product was changed. If that doesn't warrant a 5 star review, I dont know what does.
Friendliest staff ever, decent beer selection, what more could you want in a corner bodega?

You will not find nicer people working in a corner store. These guys are always so friendly. Typical convenience store snack selection, but great range of beers and decent liquor selection with crazy low prices (nice scotches!) After the world series they were giving away candy and drinks, they love the neighborhood!

I'm gonna have to go against the grain here and say that I didn't find much that I wanted here. I guess as a niche frequenter of "dirty liquor stores" and looking for certain items, I'm going on a different criteria. However the guy working that night was outside smoking and as I walked in he gave me the stink eye. Not sure why, just didn't feel right. I looked and looked, saw nothing of interest and made my way out....
Conventional wisdom says that your corner store of choice is the one that's closest to you. Conventional wisdom be damned!

I wondered whether I'm so attached to Thanasi's just because it's a block from my house, and am happy to see that I'm not irrational (or that everyone else on Yelp is equally irrational).  This place has great deals on beer, is open later than any other corner store in the area, and has a useful broad range of random stuff you might suddenly realise you need (toothpaste, crackers).  Plus, the guys who work there are SO NICE.  They tease me all the time for looking underage (a welcome compliment when you're well into your late 20s) and always give me a free mini-Reeses or fun size M&Ms when I come in.  Love them!

Thanasi's is fantastic.  It made my list of pros when I was considering moving out of the neighborhood.  They have a revolving specials on obscure beers as well as a good selection of well priced favorites.  The staff is friendly and the music gets me pumped up while I gather my pregame supplies.

Quite simply the best corner store on Earth. Some of their high end liquor prices are cheaper than BevMo (Don Julio in particular). They have great deals on beer (currently a 12 pack of Chang is $10) and they even do up to $100 cash back on ATM transactions. The guys here are friendly and they always have some bumpin' dance music playing. This place is unbeatable if you need to make a quick liquor run.
Scenario: Picking up drinks on the way to Halloween.  Then picking up some beer for a dinner cooking date.

My favorite liquor store in the city. They have the best deals - as in, you can lately pick up Trumer cases for less than a dollar a bottle - and are friendly, helpful, and outgoing. If I'm at 24th and Mission and headed up to Bernal but need to pick up drinks first, I'll go out of my way to go there for the savings and the good people, and I hate backtracking. I've more than once wondered why nowhere else seems to be able to do it like they do.
Cheap, good beer and wine .. at a corner store.
Love this place!
This place is dope.
they have welch's concord grape juice. which is made from real concord grapes. which has shitload sugar in it. which i am addicted to.
I used to live closer to M and C, and I also used to drink beer. So I used to buy beer at M and C. They have some sweet deals on six and twelve packs in this place, no joke.

I know, I know...everyone says THEIR corner-store guy is the best.  But I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a place like Thanasi's.  Say what's up to the boys, catch up on my Jon Stewart, and get tips on much better booze for my buck.  These guys are just genuinely good people.  Isn't that all one needs?

Aah Thanasi's, Remember me, when we would single handedly devastate your stocks of cheesy poofs, pot noodles and Flaming hot Cheetos Fries (which are surprisingly tasty) on any given night due to doobs and Costco Ketel one.
M & C, you give me no choice. On you I'm spending the rest of my soundtrack budget for 2006 on a very expensive song. You deserve it.
